verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन ।
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana
tat kiṃ karmaṇi ghore māṃ niyojayasi keśava
verses.translation: Arjuna, the soul still caught in ego-confusion, cries out to Krishna — the indwelling Higher Self — 'If wisdom is superior to action, why dost Thou drive me into this terrible battle? Speak clearly, O Lord; resolve this bewildering contradiction that tears my heart in two.'

word_breakdown.meaning: superior / better / more excellent
intellect / knowledge / discriminative understanding
O Janardana — one who stirs or moves the people; epithet of Krishna
in action / in this deed / in this work
terrible / dreadful / horrific
you engage / you urge / you appoint (me to)

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question here is beautifully sincere — and Dadaji always said that a sincere question is already half the answer. Arjuna has been listening to Krishna's praise of wisdom and the imperishable Self, and his simple heart draws a logical conclusion: if knowing is better than doing, why fight? This is the confusion of a good student who has heard only half the teaching. Dadaji would gently point out that Arjuna uses two of Krishna's most loving epithets here — Janardana and Kesava — as if invoking the divine friendship itself. He is not arguing; he is genuinely pleading for clarity. The word 'ghore' — terrible — reveals that Arjuna's reluctance is not laziness but a sincere moral anguish. This is the beginning of Karma Yoga's great unfolding.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's question reflects a genuine philosophical confusion that still troubles seekers today. He has heard Krishna praise jñāna (knowledge) in Chapter 2 and now asks: if knowledge is superior, why prescribe karma (action)? This is actually a deep and important question. The confusion arises from treating jñāna yoga and karma yoga as mutually exclusive alternatives rather than as complementary paths suited to different temperaments. Arjuna is also confusing the *goal* (jñāna, realization) with the *means* appropriate for him at this stage. Chapter 3 will clarify that for most people, karma yoga — selfless, unattached action — is the necessary preparation for the arising of genuine jñāna.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna represents every sincere seeker who has ever stood at the crossroads of contemplation and engagement. The soul yearns for the still wisdom of pure knowing, and yet it stands embodied in a world that seems to demand action. Yogananda taught that this is not a contradiction but a divine design — the path of selfless action in the world is itself a purification that eventually opens the inner eye to direct realization. Krishna will not choose one path and abandon the other; He will reveal how action, when purified of ego and desire, becomes a form of worship, and worship itself becomes liberation. The name 'Kesava' used by Arjuna — one who has beautiful hair, or one who slew the demon Keshi — also hints at the divine power that slays inner demonic tendencies.
commentary.goyandka: From the classical standpoint, Arjuna's question arises from a misunderstanding of the Sāṃkhya teaching Krishna gave in Chapter 2. Sāṃkhya describes the path of discriminative knowledge for renunciants; Yoga describes the path of disciplined action for those still engaged in the world. Arjuna mistakes Krishna's description of the jñānī's state for a prescription for his own conduct. Goyandka notes that the word 'matā' — considered by You, held as Your opinion — shows Arjuna is appealing to Krishna's own apparent teaching. The question is therefore not impertinent but pedagogically necessary: it creates the opening through which the doctrine of Karma Yoga will be delivered with precision and completeness.

verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे ।
तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṃ mohayasīva me
tad ekaṃ vada niścitya yena śreyo 'ham āpnuyām
verses.translation: The soul, overwhelmed by seemingly paradoxical teachings, pleads for a single, clear path. 'With one definite teaching, O Krishna, steady my wavering understanding. I stand at the crossroads between the path of wisdom and the path of action — guide me to the one that leads to the Highest Good.'

word_breakdown.meaning: mixed / seemingly contradictory / confusing / equivocal
intellect / understanding / discriminative faculty
you are causing to be deluded / you confuse / you bewilder
having determined / decidedly / conclusively
the highest good / ultimate welfare / that which is truly beneficial
I may attain / I might obtain / I could achieve

commentary.dadaji: This verse reveals Arjuna at his most honest — and Dadaji always treasured this honesty. 'Your mixed words are confusing my intellect,' he says to the Lord directly. How many of us are afraid to admit such a thing to God or to our guru? But Arjuna speaks plainly, and in that plainness there is a great surrender. The beautiful demand of the verse is in 'tad ekaṃ vada' — 'tell me that one thing.' Arjuna does not want a philosophical map; he wants a single path he can walk. Dadaji used to say: the student who asks for the one essential thing is ready to receive it. The word 'śreyas' — the highest good, true welfare — shows that Arjuna is not asking for worldly success but for genuine liberation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 2 is philosophically significant because it identifies the precise problem: vyāmiśreṇa vākyena — mixed, apparently contradictory teaching. Arjuna perceives a contradiction between the Sāṃkhya teaching (knowledge of the Self) and the Yoga teaching (disciplined action). The Vedantic resolution of this apparent contradiction is the subject of the entire Bhagavad Gītā. Arjuna's request for a single, decisive path — 'tad ekaṃ vada niścitya' — also reflects the Indian philosophical tradition's emphasis on ekāgratā, one-pointedness. The great teacher does not multiply paths unnecessarily; each student needs the one path appropriate to their temperament and stage. Krishna's answer will honor this request.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda saw Arjuna's confusion as a blessing in disguise. The mixed instructions have shaken his conventional understanding, created an inner uncertainty that makes him receptive to a deeper truth. In meditation, Yogananda taught, it is exactly this kind of cognitive dissonance — the moment when our ordinary mental frameworks prove inadequate — that opens the heart to higher guidance. Arjuna's appeal for the one path by which he may attain śreyas (the highest good) is the soul's authentic prayer. He is not asking for comfort or escape — he is asking for truth that works. And Krishna, the supreme guru, will answer with perfect precision.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that the particle 'iva' (like, as it were) used twice in this verse — mohayasīva (as if confusing), vyāmiśreṇeva (as if mixed) — is actually a respectful qualification. Arjuna does not accuse Krishna of deliberately confusing him; he acknowledges his own limited understanding by saying 'it seems to me as if.' This grammatical subtlety reveals Arjuna's humility. The request 'tell me decisively that one thing by which I may attain the highest good' is the model of how a student should approach a teacher — with total honesty about one's confusion, combined with full trust in the teacher's ability to clarify. This is the ideal guru-śiṣya relationship in action.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ ।
ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayānagha
jñāna-yogena sāṃkhyānāṃ karma-yogena yoginām
verses.translation: Krishna, the Divine Self, reveals that from the beginning of creation two paths have been taught: the path of knowledge — jñāna yoga — for those of a contemplative nature, and the path of selfless action — karma yoga — for those of an active nature. Both lead to the one Supreme.

word_breakdown.meaning: twofold / of two kinds / dual
path / foundation / steady devotion / established way of practice
O sinless one / O blameless one — epithet of Arjuna
of the Sāṃkhyas / of the contemplatives / of men of discriminative wisdom
by karma yoga / through the path of disciplined action

commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna gives the direct and decisive answer that Arjuna asked for — and notice how lovingly He addresses him: 'anagha,' O sinless one. Even before the teaching begins, the Lord reminds Arjuna of his essential purity. Dadaji often said that a true teacher first sees the student's highest nature before pointing to their confusion. The teaching itself is elegantly simple: two paths, from the very beginning — jñāna yoga for those whose nature is contemplative, karma yoga for those whose nature is active. Neither is higher in absolute terms; both lead to the same summit. The art of the spiritual life is to know which path matches your nature and to walk it wholeheartedly.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This crucial verse reveals the structural architecture of the Gītā's soteriology. Krishna says 'purā proktā mayā' — declared by Me from the beginning. This indicates these are not new inventions but eternal principles. 'Sāṃkhyānām' here refers not merely to the classical Sāṃkhya philosophy of Kapila but to those of a contemplative temperament who can directly pursue knowledge of the Self. 'Yoginām' refers to those whose natural disposition inclines toward action in the world. The key word is 'niṣṭhā' — not merely a 'path' but a steadfast, established mode of being. Both are valid; both are necessary in the world; and as Krishna will show, at a deeper level they are not truly different.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda drew attention to the divine compassion in this response. Krishna does not rebuke Arjuna for his confusion — He answers precisely, decisively, and completely. The twofold path reflects the two fundamental human types: those drawn inward toward wisdom and contemplation, and those drawn outward toward service and engagement. But Yogananda insisted that in the ideal life both paths must eventually merge. The karma yogi who works without attachment gradually develops inner stillness — which is the fruit of jñāna. The jñāna yogi whose realization deepens begins to act spontaneously and selflessly in the world — which is the flower of karma. These two paths are like two wings of the same bird.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's classical commentary emphasizes the phrase 'purā proktā mayā' — declared by Me from the beginning. This establishes the teaching as sanātana, eternal and beginningless. The Gītā is not a new teaching invented for Arjuna; it is the perennial wisdom being restated for a particular crisis at a particular moment in history. Goyandka also notes that 'niṣṭhā' implies not just a path but a complete orientation of life — a way in which one is established, grounded, steadfast. Jñāna niṣṭhā is establishment in the knowledge of the Self; karma niṣṭhā is establishment in selfless, God-dedicated action. Both are complete lifestyles, not mere techniques.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते ।
न च सन्न्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣkarmyaṃ puruṣo 'śnute
na ca sannyasanād eva siddhiṃ samadhigacchati
verses.translation: Freedom from the bondage of karma is not won by mere outer renunciation of activity. No person reaches liberation simply by refusing to act. Inaction of the body alone cannot still the restless soul. It is the inward offering of every act to God that truly liberates.

word_breakdown.meaning: freedom from action-bondage / actionlessness / the state of transcending karma
from non-commencement / by not starting (actions) / by inactivity
attains / obtains / reaches
from renunciation / by giving up (externally)
perfection / success / spiritual accomplishment / liberation

commentary.dadaji: This verse cuts through a very common spiritual misconception: that freedom from karma means simply stopping all activity. Dadaji used to say, 'You cannot run away from life — you can only run away from attachment.' A person who sits idle and calls it renunciation has not freed themselves from the law of action; they have merely become inactive while the mind continues to churn with desire. True naiṣkarmya — freedom from action-bondage — does not come from the absence of action but from the purification of the doer. When actions are performed without ego-ownership, without craving for results, the karma simply does not bind. This is the great secret that the next verses will unfold.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse demolishes what Śaṅkarācārya called 'karma-uparamaḥ' — the misconception that cessation of bodily activity is equivalent to transcendence. The term 'naiṣkarmya' is subtle: it does not mean physical inaction but the state of acting without the binding force of saṃskāra-generating desire. Similarly, 'sannyāsa' here refers to mere external renunciation — giving up the visible markers of worldly life without the inner transformation. True sannyāsa in the Vedantic sense is the renunciation of the sense of doership (kartṛtva) and enjoyership (bhoktṛtva), not merely the renunciation of possessions or roles. Outer form without inner reality achieves nothing.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda often cited this verse when advising seekers who wanted to leave the world for a monastery but whose hearts were not ready. Genuine spiritual advancement is not measured by external withdrawal but by internal detachment. The person who renounces outer life while the mind remains agitated, desirous, and ego-driven has gained nothing spiritually. Conversely, the person who remains engaged in the world — raising a family, working a profession — while maintaining inner non-attachment and God-awareness is walking the genuine path of karma yoga. The divine is not found by fleeing the world but by transforming one's relationship to it.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes the precision of this verse's double negation. 'Not by non-performance' and 'not by mere renunciation' together establish that neither extreme — compulsive action nor compulsive avoidance of action — leads to liberation. The Gītā's path is the middle way of engaged detachment. Naiṣkarmya, the state of transcending karma's binding power, is achieved only when action is performed in a spirit of complete non-attachment: without the sense of 'I am the doer' and without desire for any particular result. This requires not outer renunciation but inner transformation, which is the real subject of karma yoga. Mere idleness is tamasic, not spiritual.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् ।
कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarma-kṛt
kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ
verses.translation: Not even for a single breath can any embodied being remain completely actionless. All are helplessly propelled into activity by Nature's three qualities — the gunas — which are ever at work, even in the midst of apparent stillness. The secret lies not in stopping action, but in transforming it.

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Noun, masculine, accusative, singular (used as adverb)
word_breakdown.meaning: for a moment / even an instant
one who does no action / completely actionless
helpless / without control / involuntarily / not by one's own will
born of Prakṛti / arising from Nature
by the guṇas / by the three qualities (sattva, rajas, tamas) of Nature

commentary.dadaji: This is one of those verses where Krishna simply tells us the truth about our condition, without softening it. 'No one can remain even for a moment without acting.' Think of it — even in sleep the mind dreams, the breath continues, the heart beats. Inaction is simply not available to an embodied being. Dadaji would say: God is not asking you whether you will act — you will act regardless. He is only asking HOW you will act. Will you act driven by the unconscious force of your tendencies and desires, like a puppet of Prakṛti? Or will you act as a conscious, dedicated instrument of the divine will? That is the only real choice available to us.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse introduces one of the Gītā's most important metaphysical concepts: the unavoidability of action for an embodied being. The phrase 'prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ' — by the guṇas born of Prakṛti — points to the Sāṃkhya framework underlying the teaching. Prakṛti, Nature, is composed of three guṇas: sattva (luminosity), rajas (activity), and tamas (inertia). Every being embedded in Prakṛti is necessarily under the influence of these forces and therefore necessarily in action at all times, even if only mentally. The word 'avaśaḥ' — helplessly — is stark: without the cultivation of higher awareness, we are not the authors of our actions but their vehicles.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda found this verse both sobering and liberating. Sobering, because it reveals how little genuine freedom most people exercise — driven by their own natures, habits, and desires, they believe they are choosing when they are actually being compelled. Liberating, because it shifts the spiritual question from 'Should I act?' (which has no answer — you will) to 'From what level of consciousness will I act?' The karma yogi's discipline is precisely this: to act from ever-higher levels of awareness, gradually moving from the mechanical, unconscious action of the ego-self toward the free, spontaneous, God-directed action of the awakened soul.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka emphasizes the word 'hi' (indeed) and 'jātu' (ever) in this verse as indicators of an absolute, universal truth. This is not a conditional statement but a metaphysical fact about embodied existence. No being with a body and a mind can be physically inactive — and even apparent inactivity is itself a form of action sustained by the guṇas. The traditional commentators therefore conclude that since one must act, the question is only whether action will be performed with discrimination and dedication (karma yoga) or with the mechanical, desire-driven quality of ordinary worldly action. The Gītā's teaching is thus urgently practical: it addresses the actual condition of the human being as it is.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् ।
इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya ya āste manasā smaran
indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate
verses.translation: That soul who, in delusion, restrains the organs of action outwardly while the mind secretly dwells on sense objects — such a hypocrite, self-deceived, has merely changed the theater of desire from body to mind. True renunciation begins not with the hands but with the purified heart.

word_breakdown.meaning: the organs of action — hands, feet, speech, reproductive and eliminative organs
having restrained / after controlling / while holding back
the objects of the senses / sense pleasures / sense-objects
one whose self is thoroughly deluded / a confused soul
one of false conduct / hypocrite / one whose practice is a pretense

commentary.dadaji: This verse is a gentle but very direct warning against the spiritual performance that the heart knows is hollow. Dadaji called this the 'Pharisee verse' of the Gītā — the person who performs all the right external observances while the mind wanders through every desire it has been denied. We have all encountered this in ourselves: sitting for meditation while mentally planning, restraining the hand from reaching for something while the desire burns bright in the heart. Krishna calls this 'mithyācāra' — false conduct, hypocrisy. True spiritual practice is not the control of the outer instruments but the transformation of the inner one. The mind's dwelling on sense-objects is itself a subtle form of action that perpetuates bondage.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse makes a sharp philosophical distinction that is central to Advaita Vedānta's understanding of karma yoga. The organs of action (karmendriyāṇi) are the external instruments — hands, feet, and so on. But these are not the source of action's binding power. The binding power comes from the mind's engagement — specifically from 'smaran indriyārthān,' mentally remembering, dwelling upon, dwelling in desire for sense-objects. True renunciation, in the Vedantic sense, is therefore primarily a mental act. One can be in the midst of vigorous outer activity and be less bound than one who sits in apparent stillness while the mind races. Śaṅkara comments that this verse directly refutes the notion that physical sannyāsa automatically confers liberation.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda used this verse in his teachings on authentic spiritual practice. He pointed out that the body can be trained to external stillness far more easily than the mind can be brought to genuine quiet. A practitioner who mistakes the performance of spiritual forms — the crossed legs, the regulated breath, the folded hands — for actual spiritual practice has fallen into what Krishna calls 'vimūḍhātmā' — self-delusion. The true measure of spiritual progress, Yogananda taught, is not how long one can sit or how many rituals one can perform, but how genuinely the mind is drawn away from sense-craving and toward the inner light of the Self. Only that genuine inner turning constitutes real practice.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's commentary notes that this verse is a direct refutation of a specific school of thought — sometimes called Kriyā-Sannyāsa — that holds that the mere outward abandonment of action (sitting idle, giving up household life) constitutes sufficient spiritual practice. The Gītā emphatically disagrees. The binding force of karma operates through the mind's desire, not through the body's movement. Therefore, one who controls the body while mentally dwelling in sense-desire has accomplished nothing of spiritual value. In fact, such a person is 'vimūḍhātmā' — self-deluded — and 'mithyācāra' — a practitioner of falsehood. This is a strong condemnation, meant to push the seeker toward genuine inner purification.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन ।
कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate 'rjuna
karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
verses.translation: Truly blessed is the one who, having mastered the senses through the power of a disciplined mind, engages outwardly in the path of selfless action — karma yoga — without inner attachment. Such a soul performs all work as sacred offering, and through this very action attains the Divine.

word_breakdown.meaning: with the mind / through the mind / by means of the mind
having controlled / after restraining / controlling first
begins / undertakes / engages in

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past participle used as adjective, masculine, nominative
word_breakdown.meaning: without attachment / unattached / free from clinging
excels / is distinguished / surpasses / is superior

commentary.dadaji: After the sharp warning of verse 6, Krishna now holds up the ideal of verse 7 — and the contrast is luminous. The person who excels (viśiṣyate) does two things simultaneously: controls the senses with the mind (inner mastery), and then engages in karma yoga through the organs of action without attachment (outer engagement). Dadaji used to say this is the portrait of the truly free person — free not from the world but free within it. The key word is 'manasā' — with the mind. It is the mind that must first be directed, purified, and steadied. Only from that foundation of inner control can truly unattached action flow. This is the hero Krishna is calling Arjuna to become.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This key verse — one of the most cited in Chapter 3 — defines karma yoga in its essence. Three elements constitute the karma yogi's action: first, 'manasā niyamya' — the senses are controlled at the level of the mind, which is the right level; second, 'karmendriyaiḥ... ārabhate' — action is then actively undertaken through the organs of action; third, 'asaktaḥ' — all this is done without attachment. This is the integration of inner control and outer engagement that distinguishes karma yoga from both withdrawal and compulsive worldly action. The word 'viśiṣyate' — he excels, he is distinguished — indicates a superlative quality. This person surpasses both the idle non-actor and the ego-driven actor.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda called this the verse of the liberated worker. The karma yogi does not flee the world; the karma yogi transforms the world by transforming the quality of engagement. 'Manasā niyamya' — controlling with the mind — points to the practice of interiorization that Yogananda taught through Kriyā Yoga: withdrawing the life-force inward to the spine and brain, then redirecting it outward through the instruments of the body in service. The result is action that is fully engaged yet completely free. Such a person moves through the world like a lotus leaf on water — fully present, yet never wet. This verse is the definition of 'yoga in action.'
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's commentary emphasizes the sequence implied in this verse: first the inner, then the outer. 'Niyamya' is a gerund — it denotes an action completed before the main verb. The mind-level control of the senses must precede the engagement in karma yoga. This sequence is spiritually significant: one cannot perform genuine karma yoga — truly unattached action — without first having cultivated some degree of mental equanimity. This is why the Gītā's teaching on karma yoga is preceded by and woven together with the teaching on sthitaprajña (steady wisdom) in Chapter 2. The outer practice of yoga rests on an inner foundation of equanimity and discrimination.

verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ ।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ
śarīra-yātrāpi ca te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ
verses.translation: Therefore, O Arjuna, fulfill thy divinely appointed duty. Righteous action is far superior to the lethargy of inaction. Even the body's sustenance cannot be maintained without some form of activity. Act — but act as an instrument of the Divine, free from the fever of personal desire.

word_breakdown.grammatical_form: Past participle used as adjective / adverb, neuter
word_breakdown.meaning: prescribed / regulated / ordained / one's own duty according to nature and station
better / superior / more excellent
than inaction / compared to non-action / from not acting
the journey of the body / maintenance of the body / bodily subsistence
would be accomplished / could succeed / might be fulfilled

commentary.dadaji: After the philosophy, the practical command: 'Niyataṃ kuru karma' — perform your prescribed duty. These three words are the heartbeat of Chapter 3. Dadaji loved this directness. Krishna is not lost in abstraction — He comes straight to the point. Do your duty. Action is better than inaction — not because action is intrinsically noble, but because for an embodied being, purposeful, dutiful action is the field in which liberation is cultivated. And then the most grounded of arguments: you cannot even maintain this body without action. You must eat, breathe, care for yourself. Life itself demands engagement. The spiritual question is not 'Shall I act?' but 'Shall I act consciously and selflessly, or unconsciously and selfishly?'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'niyataṃ karma' — prescribed duty — is important. This is not any action but svadharma, one's own duty according to one's nature, capacity, and station in life. The Gītā has consistently distinguished between action in alignment with one's dharma and action driven by desire or social pressure. The argument 'karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ' — action is indeed superior to inaction — is a pragmatic one: given that verse 5 has established that no one can remain inactive, the choice is between conscious, dharmic action and unconscious, mechanical, desire-driven non-action that is actually subtle action in disguise. The body-maintenance argument ('śarīra-yātrāpi') grounds the teaching in biological reality.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda often cited this verse to address the spiritual seeker's temptation toward quietism — the belief that doing nothing is somehow more holy than doing something. Krishna firmly and lovingly corrects this. Even at the most basic level, life requires action: you must breathe, eat, move, care for the body that houses the soul. These are not distractions from spiritual life — they are its very ground. The karma yogi sanctifies every act of maintenance, every necessary duty, by performing it with awareness, without ego, and in dedication to God. The cooking, the cleaning, the earning of bread — all become yoga when the inner orientation is right.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that 'niyatam karma' specifically refers to the duties prescribed by the Vedic scriptures according to one's āśrama (stage of life) and varṇa (nature and function). For Arjuna as a kṣatriya, this prescribed duty is the protection of dharma through righteous battle. The verse thus has an immediate application to Arjuna's situation: not fighting is not actually inaction — it is a wrong action, a failure of dharma. The body-maintenance argument (śarīra-yātrā) is used here not to glorify bodily life but to demonstrate the inescapability of action. If even the minimum of bodily maintenance requires action, how much more does the full flourishing of one's human and spiritual potential require engaged, dharmic activity.

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

tad-arthaṃ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samācara
verses.translation: Every act performed without the sacred spirit of yajña — of offering to God — binds the soul in the web of karma. But the wise, O Arjuna, perform all actions as worship, offering the fruits at the altar of the Divine. Thus they move through the world untouched, free as lotus blossoms on water.

commentary.dadaji: This verse introduces the concept of yajña — sacrifice — as the liberating principle of all karma yoga. Dadaji used to explain yajña not as a ritual fire ceremony but as any action performed as an offering, without personal agenda. When you cook, if you cook as an offering to God and to those who will eat — that is yajña. When you work, if you work as service to the divine in all beings — that is yajña. The moment the ego steps in and claims the result — 'this is mine, this is for me' — the action becomes binding karma. The moment the same action is offered up, surrendered, performed as service — it becomes liberating yajna. 'Mukta-saṅgaḥ samācara' — perform, free from all attachment — is the complete formula of karma yoga.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'yajña' in this verse carries its broadest Vedantic meaning: any action performed as an offering to the cosmic order, to dharma, to the divine. Śaṅkarācārya interprets 'yajñārthāt karma' as action performed for the sake of Brahman — the ultimate reality — or for Īśvara, the personal God. The binding principle of karma is not action itself but the ego's claim on action and its results. When that claim is dissolved through the spirit of offering, the action generates no binding saṃskāra. It is performed, it is completed, and it is released. This is the deepest meaning of 'mukta-saṅgaḥ' — one whose attachment has been liberated — not merely a person who is indifferent but one who has genuinely relinquished ego-ownership of actions.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda saw yajña as the cosmic principle of selfless giving that sustains all life. Every breath, every heartbeat, every act of creation is a form of sacrifice — life giving to life. When a human being consciously aligns with this principle — performing every action as an offering, receiving every result as a gift — the individual self begins to expand into the universal Self. This is the mystical dimension of karma yoga: the practitioner who truly acts as yajña gradually realizes that the separate doer never really existed. There is only the cosmic dance of giving and receiving, and the 'I' that thought it was performing the yajña was always itself a part of the divine offering.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's classical commentary explains that 'yajñārthāt karma' originally referred to the Vedic injunction to perform all actions — including one's daily duties and livelihood — as part of the cosmic yajña that sustains dharma and the social and natural order. The universe itself operates as a yajña: rain feeds the earth, the earth feeds living beings, living beings breathe and act and eventually return their elements to the earth. When human beings consciously participate in this cosmic circulation of giving — performing their duties as offerings rather than as ego-enterprises — they align with the deepest current of existence and are carried by it toward liberation. The alternative is 'karma-bandhana' — bondage to the results of self-motivated action.

सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः ।
अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् ॥

śrī-bhagavān uvāca

anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vo 'stv iṣṭa-kāmadhuk
verses.translation: In the dawn of creation, God fashioned humanity together with the spirit of yajña — sacred, selfless offering — and declared: 'By this mutual sacrifice shall ye flourish. May this offering be your divine wish-fulfilling tree, the Kamadhenu of all your deepest aspirations.'

commentary.dadaji: Verse 10 is one of the great mythological verses of the Gītā — and Dadaji always brought its teaching alive with warmth. Prajāpati, the Creator, creates beings not in isolation but together with yajña, the spirit of sacrifice and offering. This is not an incidental detail — it is a declaration about the deepest nature of creation. The universe itself is built on the principle of mutual giving. Prajāpati then promises: live by this principle of yajña and you will prosper; this spirit of offering will be your kāmadhuk, your wish-fulfilling cow, satisfying all your genuine needs. Dadaji used to say: the truly generous person is never poor. The person who gives freely finds that life itself pours back in abundance.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse grounds karma yoga in a cosmological framework. The creation itself — 'prajāḥ' — was created 'saha-yajñāḥ,' along with the principle of yajña. This means yajña is not an invention of human religious culture but is woven into the very fabric of existence. Prajāpati, the creative principle, ordained from the beginning that the flourishing of creation is tied to the practice of mutual offering and sustenance. Swami Sarvapriyananda would note that this verse transforms karma yoga from a personal spiritual technique into a participation in the cosmic order. When we act selflessly, we are not merely improving our own spiritual condition — we are contributing to the sustenance of the entire cosmic web of life.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda saw this verse as revealing the divine secret of abundance. The universe was created on the principle of giving — and the more consciously a human being participates in this giving, the more fully they are aligned with the creative force itself. The kāmadhuk — wish-fulfilling cow — is the principle that genuine selfless service to life generates its own abundance, its own fulfilment. This is not a commercial transaction ('give and get back'); it is an organic law of life. The tree that produces fruit does not become impoverished by giving — it fulfills its nature. The person who acts as yajña fulfills their own deepest nature and in doing so finds that all genuine needs are met.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka traces this verse to the Vedic tradition of the cosmic yajña that underlies all sacrificial teaching. The Puruṣa-sūkta of the Ṛg Veda describes creation itself as a cosmic sacrifice. Prajāpati, identified in various texts with Brahmā or with the Vedic concept of the cosmic Person, establishes yajña as the mechanism of creation, preservation, and flourishing. 'Anena prasaviṣyadhvam' — by this shall you multiply — refers not merely to biological reproduction but to prosperity, growth, and the fulfillment of human life in all its dimensions. The kāmadhuk image is powerful: just as the divine cow gives milk perpetually to those who tend her, so the cosmic principle of yajña rewards those who practice it with inexhaustible fulfilment.

verses.sanskrit:

verses.translation: Through sincere devotion and selfless offering, nourish the divine forces that sustain creation, and those same divine forces shall nourish thee in return. This cosmic reciprocity — giving to the whole — is the law of the universe. Mutual upliftment is the very heartbeat of existence.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji reveals a living covenant of love between humanity and the divine. Every act of sincere sacrifice — every selfless offering of our labours, our food, our prayers — ascends like incense to nourish the gods who preside over the cosmic forces. In return they shower rains, health, inspiration, and grace. This is not a transaction but a family bond: children offering to parents who lovingly provide in return. 'Bhāvayata' — cherish, cause to bloom. The Lord does not say merely 'feed' the gods but 'cause them to flourish'. When we uplift the divine through consecrated action, the divine uplifts us. Mutual flourishing is the great secret of spiritual life. This yajna-chain restores the original joy for which creation itself was poured forth by Brahma.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws attention to the Vedic vision of cosmic interdependence underlying this verse. The Vedic sacrificial system was not mere ritual but a philosophy: the universe runs on a principle of giving. The gods — cosmic powers governing rain, fire, wind — depend on human worship and offering; humans depend on the gods for the forces of nature. The Sanskrit 'bhāvayantaḥ' — nourishing each other in the present-active participle — implies an ongoing, dynamic relationship, not a one-time exchange. Vedānta sees in this verse a pointer to Brahman as the ground of all interconnection. When the ego dissolves into this vast cycle of mutual support, the individual realizes their own infinite nature and thus gains 'param śreyas' — the supreme good that transcends any particular benefit.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda sees this cosmic nourishment as the law of vibration and attunement. The 'gods' are not remote mythological beings but divine qualities and cosmic energies — intelligence, life-force, love — that interpenetrate all creation. When through meditation, service, and right action we tune our consciousness upward, we resonate with these higher vibrations; they in turn amplify our inner light. Yogananda taught that yoga itself is the supreme yajna: the inward offering of breath and ego-sense into the fire of divine awareness. 'Parasparaṃ bhāvayantaḥ' — as we elevate our consciousness, cosmic intelligence responds by elevating us further. This reciprocal ascent is the purpose of human life: through God-attunement, to ultimately realize our oneness with the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka explains this verse as the foundational principle of the Vedic social and cosmic order. The gods — Indra, Varuna, Agni, Vayu and others — are the controllers of natural forces. They are energized and pleased by human yajnas performed according to scriptural injunction. Pleased gods then bestow timely rains, health, progeny, and prosperity. This is not superstition but the Vedic science of cosmic cause and effect. 'Śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha' — you shall attain the supreme welfare. Goyandka notes that this welfare extends beyond material prosperity to liberation itself, because a life lived in dutiful yajna purifies the mind, reduces selfishness, and ultimately leads the aspirant to the Self-knowledge that is mokṣa. The yajna cycle is thus both a practical and a spiritual imperative.

verses.sanskrit:
इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः ।

tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
verses.translation: The celestial powers, nourished by your offerings and devotion, shall shower upon you all the gifts of life and grace. But the one who enjoys these gifts without returning them in gratitude and service to the whole — that one is indeed a thief, stealing from the great treasury of the Divine.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji emphasizes the moral gravity of this verse with tender directness. Every breath we draw, every morsel we taste, every sunrise we behold is a gift from the divine forces that sustain life. To receive these gifts in a spirit of ownership — as though they are ours by right — while giving nothing back in love, service, or worship, is spiritual theft. The Lord's word 'stena' — thief — is arresting. The thief takes what belongs to another. When we hoard the world's bounty in the ego's small vault, we steal from the sacred trust of creation. But the remedy is not guilt; it is gratitude transformed into offering. Every meal becomes a yajna, every act of love a return gift. The heart that gives freely becomes the heart that is always full.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda unpacks the ethical philosophy embedded here. The Vedic tradition establishes five great debts (pañca-ṛṇas): to the gods, to the seers, to ancestors, to humanity, and to creatures. We are born into these debts and a life of yajna — ritual, charity, study, service — is how we honour them. The verse does not condemn enjoyment but enjoins responsibility. 'Tair dattān apradāyaibhyo' — receiving the gods' gifts without giving back — creates what modern ethics calls an asymmetric moral relationship. In Vedāntic terms, the ego that only takes reinforces the illusion of separateness. Every act of giving, by contrast, dissolves the ego-boundary and moves the aspirant toward the experience of non-dual unity that is liberation.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda interprets 'theft' here as the spiritual crime of self-absorption. God pours the whole universe into every soul — sunlight, food, intelligence, love. When we consume these gifts while directing consciousness only inward and downward toward sense pleasure, we steal the divine energy meant to flow onward through us to others. Yogananda taught tithing of energy: just as we offer a portion of income in charity, we must offer attention, time, and love to God and to creation. 'Yajña-bhāvitāḥ devā' — gods nourished by sacrifice — point to those cosmic centres of Divine Intelligence through which God's light flows. To enjoy the light without turning back to its Source in gratitude and meditation is to cut oneself off from an infinite reservoir.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka gives a crisp classical reading: the gods are the legitimate owners of the world's goods. They grant us enjoyment as a loan, not as an outright gift. To use their loan without repaying through yajna is theft, pure and simple. This is not metaphor but Vedic law. Goyandka notes Śaṅkara's commentary here: one who does not perform the five great yajnas (pañca-mahāyajña) — deva-yajña, pitṛ-yajña, ṛṣi-yajña, manuṣya-yajña, bhūta-yajña — is guilty of this theft even if he performs no outwardly criminal act. The social teaching is equally strong: wealth hoarded by those who do not give is ill-gotten. The spirit of yajna — giving back — is the basis of a just and harmonious society.

bhuñjate te tv aghaṃ pāpā ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt
verses.translation: The righteous who partake of what remains after sacred offering — the prasāda — are cleansed of all sin and nourished in body and spirit. But those who cook only for themselves, eating without offering or gratitude, consume not food but their own karmic bondage.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji teaches that what we eat shapes our consciousness. The food offered first to God and then received as prasāda carries divine vibrations; it purifies not only the body but the subtle mind. 'Yajña-śiṣṭa' — the remnant of sacrifice — is sacred because it has been touched by divine acceptance. The 'santo' — the good, the righteous — understand this and make every meal a ritual of offering before eating. Contrast this with those who cook solely for personal satisfaction, driven by appetite. Their every meal reinforces self-centredness, which is the root of all sin. The teaching is practical: begin the day with offering — to God, to guests, to the hungry — and what you then eat will nourish both body and soul.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda connects this verse to the Vedic institution of the pañca-mahāyajña (five great daily sacrifices). The householder was enjoined to offer to gods, ancestors, sages, fellow humans, and creatures before eating. The 'remnant' is what remains after these offerings. Philosophically, this practice dismantles ahankāra — the ego that says 'this is mine'. The verb 'mucyante' — they are freed — is significant: liberation is not only a fruit of meditation but also of right social and ritual action. Those who cook only for themselves ('ātma-kāraṇāt') trap themselves in the cycle of karma by tightening the ego-knot with every meal. Food becomes karma when consumed in selfishness, and prasāda when received with gratitude.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda sees in this verse a law of spiritual nutrition. Food carries prāṇa — life-force — and the consciousness of the preparer and the purpose of the cooking both infuse the food's vibrational quality. Food offered to God in devotion and received back as prasāda is magnetized with divine awareness. It nourishes not only the physical cells but the astral body. Yogananda was known to bless food before eating and to teach his disciples to offer every meal to God before eating. 'Those who cook only for themselves eat sin' — meaning they consume energy that reinforces the bodily ego, binding them more tightly to material consciousness. The spiritual aspirant transforms the mundane act of eating into a sacrament through this simple discipline of offering.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka gives a precise Dharmaśāstra reading: before eating, the householder must perform the five great sacrifices daily. Only after feeding gods (through fire-ritual), sages (through study and teaching), ancestors (through water libation), fellow humans (through hospitality), and creatures (through putting out food) may he eat his own meal. What he then eats is 'yajña-śiṣṭa' — the lawful remainder. Goyandka cites Manu and other smṛti authorities who hold that the householder who eats without these prior offerings is guilty of the gravest social sin. This is not asceticism but ordered social responsibility. The verse thus supports the Gītā's broader argument: Karma Yoga — selfless, disciplined action — is not an optional refinement but the very basis of dharmic life.

verses.sanskrit:

verses.translation: All creatures are sustained by food; food springs from the blessing of rain; rain descends through righteous sacrifice — yajña; and sacrifice itself is born of right action — karma. Thus every living being is woven into the great sacred web of divine interdependence.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji rejoices in this cosmic chain as a revelation of divine generosity. How intimately God has woven every link of sustenance! Beings eat food; food grows from rain; rain falls because the gods are pleased by our yajnas; and yajna itself arises when we act. Nothing is random — everything is connected through a great web of giving. Our bodies are literally made of the gifts of God and of every farmer, cloud, and sacred fire that came before us. When we see this clearly, the ego's small claim — 'this is mine, I earned this, I deserve this' — dissolves into wonder and gratitude. Dadaji would say: 'Your very breath is a gift. How can you hoard what you did not create?' This understanding is the deepest motivation for yajna.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda presents this as the Gītā's ecological and metaphysical ecology. Modern science confirms part of the chain: the water cycle, photosynthesis, the food web. But the Gītā adds a dimension science does not measure: the causal role of conscious, morally ordered action. 'Yajñāt parjanyo' — rain from sacrifice — points to the Vedic understanding that the moral quality of human action affects the natural order. A society that gives, that lives in the spirit of yajna, maintains cosmic balance. A society given to pure consumption disrupts it. This is not naive superstition but a profound insight: consciousness and cosmos are not separate. The Vedic concept of ṛta — cosmic order — is upheld by dharmic action. Karma Yoga is therefore not merely personal salvation but planetary service.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda reads this causal chain as a description of spiritual law at every level of creation. At the gross level: food sustains the body. At the subtle level: prāṇa (cosmic life-force, the inner 'rain') sustains the astral body. At the causal level: the sacrifice of ego-identity releases the soul's prāṇa into divine channels. The 'rain' that feeds spiritual growth is the descent of grace — which is activated by the yajna of meditation, service, and devotion. 'Karma-samudbhavaḥ' — arising from action — Yogananda interprets as the soul's inherent impulse to express divine love in action. The entire chain, from cosmic manifestation back to the Absolute, is God playing the game of giving and receiving with Himself through the medium of creation.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka traces the logical sequence precisely. Beings need food; food needs rain; rain needs the gods' cooperation; the gods are activated by yajna; yajna requires action (karma). The chain establishes that karmic duty — performing one's prescribed actions — is not merely personal but cosmically necessary. Any break in the chain — humans refusing to perform yajna, gods withholding rain, food failing — causes universal suffering. Goyandka stresses the word 'samudbhavaḥ' — well-arisen, properly originated: action must be the right kind of action, performed in the spirit of offering (yajna), not merely any random effort. This is why the Gītā teaches Karma Yoga — not just action, but action as worship, embedded in the sacred cycle.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji illuminates the magnificent ascent traced in this verse. First, our action (karma) must be rooted in Brahman — the sacred Veda, divine wisdom, the revealed Word of God. Not mere personal ambition or social custom, but the eternal dharma. And where does the Veda itself come from? From Akshara — the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, the Absolute. So action, properly performed, connects every human moment to the Infinite. And because all-pervading Brahman is eternally established in yajna, every selfless act of offering is a point of contact with the divine. Dadaji would say: 'When you act in the spirit of God's will and God's wisdom, you act as God Himself acting in the world. That is the glory of Karma Yoga.'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda unpacks two usages of 'Brahman' in this verse. The first — 'karma brahmodbhavaṃ' — refers to Brahman as the Vedas (śabda-brahman), the scriptural revelation that prescribes right action. The second — 'brahmākṣara-samudbhavam' — refers to Akshara, the Supreme Transcendent Brahman from which the Vedas themselves emerge. This is a cosmological ladder: Supreme Brahman → Vedic revelation → prescribed action → yajna → rain → food → beings. The implication is that when a human being performs action in accordance with the Vedas, in the spirit of yajna, they align themselves with the entire cosmic hierarchy from the material world all the way up to the Absolute. This is the metaphysical depth behind the seemingly ritual instruction of Karma Yoga.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda finds in 'akṣara' the key teaching: the Imperishable, the AUM, the Cosmic Vibration from which all sacred scripture and all creation emanates. He taught that the Vedas are not merely books but vibrations of divine consciousness crystallized into sound. All right action (karma) flows from alignment with this divine vibration. 'Sarva-gataṃ brahma nityaṃ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam' — the all-pervading Brahman is eternally established in sacrifice — means that AUM, the divine presence, is not somewhere else but right here in every sincere act of giving and offering. Meditation on AUM is thus the supreme yajna: the offering of one's individual consciousness back into the ocean of divine Consciousness from which it arose.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka carefully distinguishes the two Brahmans in this verse, following Śaṅkara. 'Brahman' in 'brahmodbhavam' refers to the Vedas — the source of prescribed duty (karma). 'Akshara' is the supreme Imperishable Brahman — the source of the Vedas themselves. This establishes the complete metaphysical pedigree of human duty: it is not arbitrarily imposed by society or rulers but descends from the Absolute through the Vedic revelation into the fabric of cosmic order. Therefore, to perform one's prescribed duty in the spirit of yajna is to participate in the Absolute. 'Nityaṃ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam' — eternally established in sacrifice: this 'eternity' means the yajna-principle is not historically contingent but a permanent feature of the relationship between the individual and the Absolute.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji speaks here with the compassion of a parent watching a child waste a precious inheritance. This wheel — cakra — is the great gift of creation, a living system of cosmic reciprocity in which every being has a meaningful, honoured role. To opt out — to live purely for one's own pleasure, consuming without giving, taking without offering — is to betray one's divine birthright. 'Moghaṃ jīvati' — lives in vain. Not wickedly, not criminally (though sin is involved), but emptily — like a lamp that hoards its oil instead of burning. Dadaji taught that the most tragic life is not a life of obvious wrongdoing but a life of missed opportunity for love and service — a life that passes through the world leaving no fragrance of selfless offering behind it.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda reads 'cakra' as the wheel of dharma — the interlocking system of cosmic, social, and individual duties that sustain both material and spiritual order. 'Nānuvartayati' — does not follow — implies both refusal and ignorance. The person given to 'indriyārāma' — sense-sport — is so absorbed in immediate pleasure that they cannot perceive the larger wheel they are part of. Vedānta diagnoses this as avidyā — ignorance of one's true nature. We are not isolated consumers but nodes in a vast field of consciousness. To live as though we are only separate, pleasure-seeking egos is not merely morally wrong but metaphysically confused. 'Mogham' resonates with one of Vedānta's deepest concerns: the 'wasted' human birth that could have been used to attain liberation.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda interprets 'indriyārāma' — delighting in the senses — as the fundamental spiritual error: taking the theatre of the senses to be ultimate reality. The senses offer only fleeting, fragmentary pleasures; the Self offers unending, unconditional bliss. To spend a human lifetime chasing sense-objects is, in Yogananda's metaphor, like a king who has forgotten his palace and is rooting around in dustbins. 'Moghaṃ jīvati' — lives in vain. The great waste is not of money or time but of the singular human capacity for God-realization. Yogananda taught that every other species lives by instinct and sense; only the human being has the developed nervous system and intellect required for the inward journey. To squander that capacity is the true tragedy.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka expounds the compound 'aghāyuḥ' with characteristic precision. Agha means both sin and the suffering that follows sin. So 'aghāyuḥ' denotes one whose life-breath (āyus) is pervaded by both sin and its inevitable pain. Such a person goes through the motions of living — eating, working, sleeping — but never fulfils the human purpose. Goyandka insists on the social dimension: one who breaks the yajna-chain does not merely harm himself but weakens the cosmic and social fabric that sustains all others. The verse is therefore a warning against both personal hedonism and social irresponsibility. Dharmic action — selfless, scripture-guided, offered as yajna — is not optional extra virtue but the minimum obligation of a being who has received the extraordinary gift of human birth.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji sees this verse as the Gītā's most tender acknowledgment: the fully God-realized soul is free. When the heart is flooded with the joy of the Self — not the ego-self but the divine Ātman, the indwelling God — nothing in the outer world can add to or subtract from that completeness. Such a soul may still act, and act with great energy and compassion, but not from duty or fear or desire. Dadaji would describe this as the state of a truly surrendered devotee: all giving now flows as naturally as the river flows to the sea — not because the river must, but because that is its nature. The 'ātma-ratiḥ' is not withdrawn from the world; they are fully in the world but not of it, acting from fullness rather than from need.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda identifies this as the pivotal verse of the Gītā's teaching on karma and jñāna. The three qualifications given — ātma-ratiḥ (delighting in Self), ātma-tṛptaḥ (satisfied in Self), ātmany eva santuṣṭaḥ (content in Self) — are not redundant but progressively deeper: joy, fulfilment, and abiding contentment. These describe the jñānī who has realized Ātman as the only reality. For such a person, the prescriptions of yajna and karma no longer bind, because the entire purpose of those prescriptions — to purify the mind, reduce ego-attachment, and prepare for Self-knowledge — has been accomplished. This is the Vedāntic principle: action is a means to knowledge; once knowledge dawns, the means is no longer necessary.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda calls this the description of the Paramahansa — the supreme swan who has crossed the ocean of delusion. 'Ātma-ratiḥ' — rejoicing in the Self — corresponds to the state of samādhi, where consciousness rests in its own infinite nature and finds there a bliss that no sense experience can approximate. Yogananda taught: 'Seek ye first the kingdom of God' — this is ātma-tṛpti, inner satisfaction. Once that inner kingdom is found, outer duties transform in character. The sage may still teach, serve, and guide, but they do so as instruments of divine will, not as obligated egos. Their action is spontaneous divine expression — like sunlight that shines not out of duty but because that is its nature.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka addresses a potential misunderstanding directly: this verse does not give an excuse to the unenlightened person to abandon duties. The exemption applies only to the utterly Self-realized — one who has directly experienced the Ātman as the fullness of existence. For all others, the prescribed duties of yajna, karma, and dharma remain binding. Goyandka cites Śaṅkara: just as a person who has crossed the river no longer needs the ferry, the Self-realized person has no use for karma as a vehicle to liberation. But until that shore is reached, to abandon the boat mid-river is not liberation — it is drowning. The verse is therefore a beacon of the goal, not permission to abandon the path before reaching it.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji points to this verse as the portrait of perfect inner freedom. The realized soul has no interest in results — not because they are indifferent or cold, but because they are already complete. 'Kṛtena' — by what is done, 'akṛtena' — by what is not done: neither success nor failure, neither achievement nor omission touches the deep peace of the one established in the Self. And 'na cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ' — they do not depend on any being for any object. This does not mean they live in isolation; it means their well-being, joy, and security rest entirely in God. They love all beings but need nothing from them. This freedom from need is what makes their love truly unconditional — the pure love that gives without expectation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda reads this verse in conjunction with verse 17 as the Gītā's description of the jīvan-mukta — the one liberated while living. Two kinds of freedom are indicated. First, freedom from the injunctions: 'kṛtena arthaḥ na' — no personal gain from action, 'akṛtena arthaḥ na' — no personal loss from inaction. The karma-yoga practitioner moves toward this by performing action without personal stake in results. Second, freedom from dependency: 'artha-vyapāśrayaḥ na' — no dependence on any being. This points to the Ātman's self-sufficiency (svayaṃ-prabhu). The liberated person may accept or reject relationships, food, and service freely, but their fundamental being does not depend on any external source. This is Vedānta's definition of absolute freedom: pūrṇatva — completeness.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda describes this state as 'cosmic consciousness' — the state in which the individual awareness has merged with the universal. For such a being, action and inaction are equally irrelevant to identity. They act because it is divine play (līlā), not because they need to accomplish something. And their relationship to other beings is one of universal love without personal dependency. Yogananda taught: 'The saint is not aloof from the world but detached within it.' They move through relationships like a lotus in water — fully present, fully loving, yet untouched. 'Artha-vyapāśrayaḥ' — needing no object or being for sustenance — describes one who has found the inner spring of divine bliss that makes all outer fountains redundant, though still beautiful.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka treats this as the classical definition of the sthita-prajña — the one of steady wisdom — elaborated here from the perspective of karma. He notes that 'arthaḥ' encompasses both worldly gain and dharmic merit: the Self-realized person has no concern for either. They perform no action to acquire merit (puṇya) and lose no merit by omission. Furthermore, 'na artha-vyapāśrayaḥ' — no dependence for any purpose — means they do not engage in social relationships out of need, fear, or desire. This is the positive flipside of the warning in verse 16: the 'indriyārāma' person is bound by dependence on sense-objects and other beings, while the ātma-ratiḥ is free of all such bondage. The contrast sets the goal clearly before the sādhaka.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji calls this verse the practical heart of the Gītā's Karma Yoga. 'Tasmāt' — therefore — points back to everything that has been established: the cosmic chain of yajna, the ideal of the Self-realized sage, the emptiness of a life lived only for the senses. Given all this, what should we do? 'Asaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara' — without attachment, always perform your duty. Not sometimes, not when convenient, not only when inspired — but constantly, as a way of being. And the promise is luminous: 'param āpnoti' — attains the Supreme. Not a modest reward, not mere worldly success, but the Highest — liberation, God-realization, infinite bliss. Dadaji taught that every ordinary moment of selfless, loving, God-offered action is a step on this shining road.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda presents this as the Gītā's central prescription in crystallized form. 'Asaktaḥ' — without attachment — is the operative word. The Vedāntic analysis is this: action by itself does not bind; it is the attachment to results, the ego-identification with the actor and the outcome, that creates karma and perpetuates saṃsāra. Remove attachment and action becomes a vehicle of purification. A purified mind is capable of the self-inquiry (ātma-vicāra) that leads to liberation. Thus Karma Yoga is not the goal but the indispensable preparation. 'Param āpnoti' — attains the Supreme — is the Vedāntic promise: not heaven, not rebirth in better circumstances, but the direct realization of Brahman, one's own true nature.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda reads 'asaktaḥ' as the yogi's fundamental attitude: engaged in all activities yet inwardly free, like an actor playing a role with full energy while knowing they are not the character. He taught the technique of offering all actions to God: 'I am Thine; do Thou with me what Thou wilt.' This offering dissolves attachment at its root. 'Satatam' — always, continuously — is key: Karma Yoga is not a periodic spiritual exercise but a continuous orientation of consciousness. The 'param' attained is not a future state but an ever-present reality gradually unveiled as attachment drops away. Yogananda identified this 'param' with the cosmic AUM-consciousness that underlies all action — the realization that the actor, the action, and the result are all one divine movement.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka draws out the causal relationship with precision: 'asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti' — because (hi) the unattached person acting attains the Supreme. 'Hi' is the logical connector — this is not merely recommended behaviour but a law of spiritual causation. Attachment to results causes karma; karma causes rebirth; rebirth perpetuates suffering. Remove the attachment and the chain breaks at its source. Goyandka emphasizes 'kāryam karma' — duty-action, not just any action: it must be the prescribed, dharmic action appropriate to one's station (varṇāśrama-dharma) performed in a spirit of offering. Random activity performed without attachment is not sufficient; it must be the right action, properly performed, with inward non-attachment — then, and only then, it leads to the Supreme.

commentary.dadaji: Dadaji presents King Janaka as one of the most beloved exemplars of the Gītā's teaching: a royal householder who attained the heights of Self-realization while governing a kingdom, raising a family, and performing all worldly duties. He did not renounce the world; he transformed it into a temple. 'Karmaṇaiva hi' — through action alone indeed — not despite action but by means of it. This is the Gītā's revolutionary declaration: the world is not an obstacle to God but the very field in which God is to be found and served. And 'loka-saṃgraham' — the welfare and holding-together of the world — is Krishna's gift to Arjuna: even if personal liberation were not the question, the duty of the great soul is to act for the world's good. Love alone justifies action.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda holds this verse as the Gītā's answer to the question of whether action is compatible with the highest realization. Janaka — a rāja-rṣi, royal sage — is the scriptural proof that it is. Janaka appears in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad as a great knower of Brahman who taught even the sage Yājñavalkya in certain respects. He held court, fought battles, and administered a vast kingdom — and yet was fully liberated. The word 'saṃsiddhi' — perfection, the highest accomplishment — leaves no ambiguity: this is not worldly success but mokṣa. Furthermore, 'loka-saṃgraha' introduces a purely social-ethical motivation: even the liberated sage acts for the welfare of the world, setting an example that others can follow. Action, rightly understood, is universal service.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda cites Janaka as one of the great exemplars of what he called the 'householder path' — the spiritual possibility available to those who live fully in the world. He saw in Janaka's example the fulfilment of the Karma Yoga ideal: a consciousness rooted in divine awareness, expressing itself freely through every form of worldly engagement. 'Loka-saṃgraham sampaśyan' — bearing in mind the welfare of the world — is, for Yogananda, the defining characteristic of the true master: not withdrawal but engagement, not escape but transformation. Yogananda's own life embodied this: he built institutions, taught thousands, and lived in the midst of society while never losing the inner consciousness of the Divine. He taught that the world is God's ashram and every sincere act of service is a form of worship.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka uses this verse to address the socially influential person's unique responsibility. Janaka was a king — a person whose choices, attitudes, and actions shaped the behaviour of millions. 'Loka-saṃgraha' — maintaining the cohesion and moral order of society — is identified here as an independent justification for action, separate from the question of personal liberation. Even if Arjuna were already liberated (which he is not), his duty as a kṣatriya and his social role as a warrior-leader of the Pāṇḍavas would still require him to fight. Goyandka stresses that the Gītā never advocates quietism or social withdrawal for the able-bodied person of social responsibility. 'Kartum arhasi' — you ought to act — remains the Lord's clear, unambiguous command to Arjuna throughout the entire teaching.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna reveals the profound responsibility borne by every elevated soul. The great person is not merely an individual — he is a living scripture for the world. His every act becomes a template that lesser-evolved souls, lacking inner discrimination, eagerly imitate. This is not mere social observation; it is a cosmic law. The guru, the elder, the sage — each sets a pramāṇa, a living standard of measure. Krishna is pointing gently at Himself: if the Lord of all worlds were to act lazily or abandon duty, the consequences would be catastrophic. The teaching carries a personal note for Arjuna too: as a Kshatriya chieftain, his surrender on the battlefield would give permission to thousands to similarly abandon their dharma. We become, whether we like it or not, examples. Let the example then be worthy.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws attention to the sociological depth of this verse. Human beings are fundamentally imitative creatures — we learn by watching, and we validate our choices by seeing others make them. The word śreṣṭha means not just 'superior' but the person who is looked up to, whose opinion carries pramāṇa — authority and proof. Krishna uses this observation to lay the groundwork for His own explanation of why He, the unborn, boundless Self, still acts. The wise must act with full awareness that their actions will be magnified and replicated by others. This is why the Gītā insists that wisdom must express itself in engaged, exemplary action — not in passive withdrawal, which would itself set a dangerous precedent for society.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda saw in this verse the eternal truth that evolution of consciousness spreads through living examples more powerfully than through words. The Christ, the Buddha, the great yogis — they acted in the world not because they needed to, but because their actions created magnetic channels through which others could follow toward liberation. The śreṣṭha is one whose inner realisation has become outwardly visible in every gesture, every choice. Yogananda taught that a true spiritual teacher is not someone who merely lectures on God but one who has become a living demonstration of divine law. The pramāṇa such a one sets is not a rule imposed from outside but a radiant pattern woven into reality itself, drawing aspirants naturally toward the light.
commentary.goyandka: Shri Jayadayal Goyandka notes that this verse establishes loka-saṃgraha — the holding together of the world — as a sacred duty of the wise. Society does not primarily follow ideas; it follows persons. When a person of stature acts carelessly, wrongly, or in contradiction to dharma, the ordinary person feels licensed to do the same. Conversely, the mahātmā's disciplined life quietly elevates the moral atmosphere of countless surrounding lives. Goyandka emphasises that this verse is also a warning: one who has realised the Self cannot claim that his outer life is irrelevant. Having attained inner freedom, he must manifest it responsibly, as a lamp that is lit does not hide its flame but illuminates the room.

commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna makes the most extraordinary personal disclosure of the entire Gītā. He who holds all three worlds in being, He for whom nothing remains to be gained — He yet acts. This is the mystery of the divine līlā. Dadaji taught that this verse strips away every possible selfish motive from the Lord's action, and in doing so, presents the purest model of karma yoga. The Lord acts not from need, not from desire, not from compulsion — but purely as an expression of His nature. This is precisely the standard Krishna sets for the liberated human being: act not because you must, not because you want, but because action arising from pure Being is itself an act of love. The knower of Brahman, like Krishna, has nothing to achieve — yet for the sake of the world, he continues.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda highlights the philosophical precision of this verse. Krishna distinguishes between two possible reasons for action: duty (kartavya) and desire for gain (avāptavya). He has neither. Yet He acts — varta eva. This 'eva' carries tremendous weight: 'nevertheless,' 'even so,' 'assuredly.' The liberated being's action is not a contradiction but a mystery rooted in pure compassion. Vedanta teaches that the jīvanmukta, the one liberated while alive, does not merely sit in absorption but continues to be active in the world. His activity is not driven by saṃskāras or ego but flows effortlessly like a river that has reached the sea and yet keeps flowing for the benefit of all who dwell on its banks.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda saw in this verse a revelation of divine immanence. God is not a remote, retired Creator who set the universe in motion and then withdrew. God is perpetually active — sustaining every atom, guiding every consciousness — not out of any unfulfilled longing but out of the infinite fullness of divine Love. The man of God-realisation shares in this quality: having dissolved the personal ego in the Infinite, whatever action flows through him is God's action. Yogananda wrote that the true yogi does not retire from the world to protect his realisation; he moves through the world as an instrument of the divine will, free of personal agenda, acting because Love itself is inexhaustibly active. This is the essence of being a channel for God.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka explains that this verse answers the natural question: if Krishna is the Supreme, what could possibly motivate Him to act? The answer is — nothing personal. Neither duty owed to a higher authority (there is none) nor any gap between what He has and what He desires (there is none). This is the hallmark of the perfectly free agent: action without necessity, service without compulsion. Goyandka uses this to illuminate the meaning of niṣkāma karma — desireless action. It does not mean inaction; it means action from which the gravitational pull of personal gain has been entirely removed. Only the Lord exhibits this in perfect fullness; the sādhaka moves toward it as his ego progressively dissolves in the practice of surrender.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna continues His self-disclosure with remarkable candour. Were He — the very source of dharma — to become languid and cease action, that example of inaction would cascade through all humanity. Dadaji noted that this is not a hypothetical fear but a cosmic principle: the vibrational field set by an awakened being is far more powerful than any preaching. If Krishna, who has realised all, rested in silence and withdrawal, every sincere aspirant watching would feel justified in doing the same. The word atandritaḥ — 'without sloth, without torpor' — is particularly striking: even God is described as tireless. The divine does not rest. In this lies the rebuke to all who use 'spiritual peace' as a cover for comfortable inertia.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws out the structural logic of these three verses (21-23) as a connected argument. Verse 21 establishes the sociological law of imitation. Verse 22 establishes that Krishna has no personal motive. Verse 23 applies both to explain why He must nevertheless act. The word atandritaḥ adds a quality to the action: it is not reluctant or mechanical but vigorous and fully engaged. This is significant for the karma yogi: the teaching is not merely to act, but to act with complete, undivided energy — bringing to one's appointed work the same wholeness that God brings to the sustaining of creation. Half-hearted action in the name of detachment is not karma yoga.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda's commentary on this verse focuses on the concept of spiritual authority. The liberated teacher's choices carry immense weight — not because his followers are blindly obedient but because the disciple's instinct correctly perceives that the guru's life reveals what is ultimately true. If such a one chose passivity, it would be read as a divine endorsement of retreat from life. Yogananda himself remained phenomenally active until his last breath, travelling, writing, teaching, building institutions — not from ego-drive but precisely because he understood this principle. The message of his life was: realisation does not remove you from the world; it makes you more lovingly present in it, more tirelessly useful to all.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka emphasises the phrase mama vartmānuvartante — 'they follow My path.' This reveals that the great soul's life becomes a path, a vartma, that others naturally trace. It is not merely that they hear his ideas; they feel his life as a directional pull. Goyandka connects this to the concept of the guru's anugraha — the grace that operates not through instruction alone but through the very manner of the teacher's being in the world. He warns that great souls must be mindful of their example even in seemingly small matters, for the impressionable devotee receives every signal and encodes it as dharma. This is both the burden and the glory of the enlightened: their whole life is a teaching.
