commentary.dadaji: This verse intensifies the teaching of the previous one. Krishna does not merely say 'things would be difficult' — He says the worlds themselves would utsīdeyuḥ, collapse and sink. And He, the Lord of dharma, would become the author of saṅkara — chaos, confusion, the dissolution of right order. Dadaji saw here a profound theological statement: the cosmos is not a machine that runs on its own. It is sustained moment to moment by the active participation of the divine. For the human sādhaka, this translates as: your dharma is not an optional extra. Your presence in your appointed role is part of the architecture of the world. To abandon it is not humility — it is a form of cosmic irresponsibility.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda points to the word saṅkara — confusion — which appeared earlier in Chapter 1 when Arjuna used it as one of his reasons for not fighting (fear of mixing of varṇas and destruction of family dharma). Arjuna feared he would create saṅkara by fighting; Krishna now reveals the deeper irony: it is by not acting that saṅkara arises. The wise man's failure to engage is far more destructive than any chaos that might seem to follow from his engagement. This is the dialectical heart of the karma yoga teaching: the apparent peace of inaction is the most dangerous illusion, because it abandons the field to forces that will generate far greater disorder.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda meditated deeply on what it means for God to say 'I would destroy these creatures' by inaction. It reveals that the sustaining of life is itself an active divine function — Brahman is not the passive Absolute of some philosophies but the dynamically loving Presence that holds every electron in its orbit and every soul on its evolutionary path. The implication for the spiritual seeker is luminous: your service to others, your karma yoga, your active compassion — these are participations in God's sustaining activity. To withdraw from service under a misapplied notion of transcendence is, in a real sense, to work against the divine will. God's nature is love-in-action; the realised soul reflects that nature.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka draws out the practical import of this verse for the householder. If even the Almighty would become the cause of confusion by abandoning action, how much more so the ordinary person embedded in social and family responsibilities? The verse effectively demolishes the notion that spiritual advancement requires abandonment of worldly duty. Saṅkara here means not just social disorder but the confusion within one's own being that comes from denying one's dharma. Goyandka emphasises that the Gītā nowhere asks the householder to imitate the renunciate's external form; it asks him to perform his duties as an offering to God, as worship — and this purifies the heart as completely as formal renunciation.

commentary.dadaji: The term loka-saṃgraha is one of the most luminous in the entire Gītā. Saṃgraha means not merely welfare but integration — the holding together of diverse elements into a coherent, flourishing whole. Dadaji taught that the wise person's motive for action is precisely this: not personal gain, not even the satisfaction of helping, but the vision of the entire human family as a single organism that needs its every member functioning rightly. The contrast drawn here is exquisite: both the ignorant and the wise act — the outer form is identical. What differs is the inner ground. The ignorant act from attachment to outcome; the wise act from compassion and a vision of wholeness. The Gītā does not ask us to stop acting; it asks us to transform the root of our action.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda highlights that this verse provides the positive alternative to the earlier warning about not disturbing the ignorant. The wise person does not merely tolerate the world's ordinary activity — he actively participates in it, for the sake of loka-saṃgraha. The word cikīrṣu (desiring to bring about) shows that this is not passive or resigned engagement but a living, intentional will directed toward the world's integration. Vedanta's apparent aloofness from the world is always balanced by this principle: the jñānī who knows the world as Brahman loves it unconditionally and works for its elevation, precisely because he sees its divine ground more clearly than anyone else.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda, whose life was the very definition of loka-saṃgraha, saw this verse as the mandate for all spiritual organisations and teachers. The realised being does not gather disciples for self-glorification but for the integration of humanity around a common divine centre. The āśrama, the satsaṅg, the spiritual community — these are attempts at loka-saṃgraha, at weaving diverse human beings into a harmonious fabric of shared aspiration. Yogananda emphasised that karma yoga, when practised at this level, becomes indistinguishable from divine love: it is the willingness to hold the world in one's heart and work tirelessly for its highest flowering, asking nothing in return.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes the precision of Krishna's comparison. He does not say 'act even though the ignorant act' — He says 'act just as the ignorant act' (yathā... tathā), meaning with equal vigour, equal earnestness, equal visible engagement. The only difference is asakta — the inner freedom from grasping. This is the supreme test of karma yoga: can you act with the full intensity and commitment of someone who craves the result, while remaining as internally free as someone who has renounced all results? This is the razor's edge the Gītā asks us to walk. Goyandka emphasises that this is not suppression of effort but a total redirection of effort's motivating energy — from fear and craving to love and wisdom.

commentary.dadaji: This verse reveals the pedagogy of the liberated. The wise teacher does not go about dismantling the ordinary person's framework of action by confronting them with abstract Vedantic negations. If you tell a sincere karma-saṅgī — a person whose whole moral identity is built around doing his duty rightly — that ultimately no one acts, that there is no doer, that karma is an illusion, you shatter his operative faith without giving him anything to replace it. The result is buddhi-bheda — a fracture of understanding that leads not to liberation but to moral paralysis and cynicism. Dadaji taught that the true teacher guides people through the next step of their actual evolution, not the final step of his own.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws careful attention to joṣayet — 'let him cause them to relish, to engage joyfully.' The teacher's task is not correction but inspiration. The ignorant are already acting; the wise should not subtract motivation but elevate its quality by example. The beautiful phrase yuktaḥ samācaran — 'acting himself, established in yoga' — reveals that the teaching is entirely by demonstration. The wise person's own quality of engaged, absorbed, selfless action is the instruction. Those who observe him work find their own work subtly transformed: they begin, almost unconsciously, to act with more attention, more care, more inner freedom. This is how consciousness transmits wisdom.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda often spoke of the danger of premature Vedantic instruction. To tell a person who is still building their moral and emotional foundations that 'there is no sin, no karma, no separate self' — before they have developed the inner container to hold that truth — is to rob them of the scaffolding they need. The divine teacher honours where each soul actually is and offers the next handhold on the climbing wall, not a leap to the summit. Yogananda's own approach was always this: meet people in their lives, in their duties, in their relationships, and quietly reveal how those very duties, performed with devotion, become the path to God. This is the wisdom of joṣayet — making dharma itself the joy.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka reads this verse as a corrective to a certain misuse of the previous teaching on non-doership. If a person hears 'I am not the doer' and concludes 'therefore I need not act,' he has understood the letter and lost the spirit. The wise man knows the truth of non-doership — but he does not broadcast it indiscriminately, because for the unprepared it becomes a rationalisation for laziness. Instead, he leads by example, showing how karma yoga works from the inside: total engagement externally, total freedom internally. Goyandka emphasises that the Gītā's teaching on non-doership is not a metaphysical shortcut but an advanced attainment, approached gradually through disciplined action offered as worship.

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most philosophically dense verses in the entire Gītā — the classic statement of Sāṃkhya-Yoga non-doership. All actions, sarvaśaḥ — in every possible way, without exception — are being done by the guṇas operating through prakṛti. The pure Self — the ātman — does not act; it witnesses. But the ahaṃkāra, the I-maker, superimposes itself upon the stream of action and claims: 'I am doing this.' Dadaji explained this with great care: the deluded one does not merely make an intellectual error — vimūḍhātmā means his very sense of being (ātmā) has been thoroughly confused. The error goes to the root. Liberation begins with the first genuine experiential insight: 'It is not I who acts — the body-mind-nature complex acts, and I am the silent, witnessing awareness.'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that this verse is the philosophical fulcrum of the entire karma yoga teaching. The liberation being pointed to is not a change in outer behaviour but a fundamental shift in the sense of agency. As long as I believe 'I am doing,' I am bound — because that belief entails the correlative belief 'I will receive the result.' The two arise together. When I see clearly that the guṇas are doing everything — that what I call 'my choice' is itself a configuration of sattva, rajas, and tamas playing out according to their nature — the false I-am-the-doer belief begins to dissolve. This is not fatalism; it is the beginning of true freedom, because the witness-consciousness that remains is the real Self, already free.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda translated this insight into practical terms: every time you feel pride swelling in the chest — 'I did this, I achieved that' — recognise it as ahaṃkāra-vimūḍha, the thoroughly confused ego. The body acted; the nerves acted; the habits built over lifetimes acted; the divine energy flowing through the instrument acted. The personal 'I' was the last to arrive and the first to claim credit. Yogananda's practice of offering all results to God — 'Lord, You are the Doer; I am the instrument' — is the practical antidote to this delusion. Over time, the repeated offering wears away the habit of claiming, until the yogi rests in the natural state: pure witnessing, pure presence, free from the compulsion of doership.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka's commentary here is subtle and important. He notes that recognising 'the guṇas act' is not a philosophical position to be adopted intellectually and used as a shield — 'I am not the doer, therefore I am not responsible.' That itself would be ahaṃkāra operating under a new disguise. True recognition of non-doership produces humility, not licence. When one genuinely sees that the guṇas perform all actions, the natural response is gratitude and surrender — not the smug comfort of claiming to be beyond karma. Goyandka emphasises that this verse must be received in the context of Chapter 3's overall teaching: act fully, selflessly, as an instrument — and only after long purification will the truth of non-doership dawn as living realisation rather than mere concept.

commentary.dadaji: The phrase guṇā guṇeṣu vartante is one of the most liberating formulas in all of scripture. The guṇas — sattva, rajas, tamas — move among and through each other. The sense organs (themselves guṇic modifications) contact the objects of the world (also guṇic modifications). The whole drama of perception, desire, action, and result is a play of guṇa-upon-guṇa. The ātman — pure consciousness — is not implicated. The tattva-vit, the one who knows this not merely as a concept but as living experience, is na sajjate — not attached, not caught, not hooked. Dadaji was fond of pointing out that this is not indifference: the tattva-vit sees more clearly than anyone else because his vision is unclouded by the distorting lens of 'I am doing.'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda contrasts verses 27 and 28 as the two faces of humanity: the ahaṃkāra-vimūḍhātmā who claims false doership, and the tattva-vit who sees through the entire performance. The word tu — 'but' — marks the contrast sharply. The structure guṇā guṇeṣu — guṇas in guṇas — is a brilliant compression: it says that the whole of material existence (object, organ, action, result) consists of guṇas modifying guṇas, with no room for a separate 'experiencer I' to be genuinely involved as an agent. The one who realises this lives in the world fully — acts, speaks, engages — but is like a clear lens: the light passes through without itself being coloured.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda wrote that the realisation expressed in guṇā guṇeṣu vartante is what the genuine yogi discovers in deep meditation. In samādhi, the seer withdraws from identification with body, mind, and ego and rests in pure consciousness — and looking back at the world, sees it as a vast interplay of the three qualities, none of which touches the witnessing Self. This is not an abstract philosophy; it is a directly verifiable experience. And once tasted, even in ordinary waking consciousness, the yogi carries that spacious non-attachment into all activity. He acts but is not acted upon; he loves but is not enslaved by love; he responds to the world but is not defined by the world's response to him.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka explains the word vibhāgayoḥ — knowledge of the distinction (between guṇas and actions, and between both and the ātman). True discrimination (viveka) means not just knowing that the guṇas act but knowing precisely where the boundary lies between what is guṇic and what is the pure Self. This clarity is the medicine for ahaṃkāra-vimūḍha. Goyandka emphasises that such knowledge is not gained by study alone but by persistent sādhana — by the gradual quietening of the guṇas through sattvic discipline until the witness-consciousness shines on its own. The tattva-vit is not someone who has merely read Sāṃkhya texts; he is someone who has experientially separated the strands of his own being.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna now brings together the threads of verses 25-28 into a precise practical instruction. The kṛtsna-vid — the one who knows the whole truth, who sees guṇas acting in guṇas, who has realised the ātman as non-doer — should not use this knowledge as a weapon to unsettle those who are still building their lives around action, duty, and effort. Mandān — 'the slow ones' — is not a term of contempt but of compassionate realism. Spiritual evolution has its own pace. The person who is still at the stage of karma yoga — doing their duty earnestly, attached to results, finding meaning in effort — is exactly where they need to be. Destabilising them would be cruelty dressed as knowledge.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes the beautiful contrast between akṛtsna-vid (one of incomplete knowledge) and kṛtsna-vid (one who knows the whole). The kṛtsna-vid does not condescend but serves — and serves by not interfering with processes of organic spiritual unfolding. There is a kind of spiritual impatience that wishes to rush everyone to the highest understanding immediately, but this impatience is itself a guṇic disturbance. The wise teacher has the patience of Nature herself: he plants seeds, creates conditions, models living truth — and trusts that each soul will arrive in its own season. Vicālayet — 'should not cause to waver' — implies that even well-intentioned philosophical discourse, mistimed, can do more harm than silence.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda drew a distinction between knowledge that liberates and knowledge that confuses. The same Vedantic truth — 'you are not the doer; the Self is ever free' — can either open a door or cause a crisis, depending on the readiness of the receiver. For someone who has not yet developed strong ethical foundations, renunciation of ego-sense can lead to irresponsible behaviour. For someone who has built a spiritual life through years of disciplined karma yoga, the same truth becomes the final release into freedom. Yogananda's method was always to gauge the student's level precisely before speaking. The kṛtsna-vid knows not only the truth but the timing of truth — which is itself a form of wisdom.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka relates this verse to the pedagogical tradition of adhikāra-bheda — the principle that different teachings are appropriate for different levels of spiritual qualification. The Gītā itself operates on this principle: karma yoga for those still identified with action, jñāna yoga for those ready for discrimination, bhakti yoga for those whose hearts have opened to devotion. The kṛtsna-vid recognises where each person stands and does not impose the curriculum of a higher level on one not yet prepared. Goyandka adds that this is also a teaching about the relationship between humility and wisdom: true knowledge makes one more compassionate, not more dismissive of those on earlier stages of the path.

With mind absorbed in the awareness of the higher Self, freed from personal desire and ego-fever, freed from the burning anxiety of 'mine' and 'not mine,' take up the battle with thy spirit serene. commentary.dadaji: This verse is the summit of the practical teaching of Chapter 3 — a distilled instruction of almost unbearable beauty. Mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasya — 'having surrendered all actions to Me.' This is not the renunciation of action but the renunciation of the claim upon action. Every act becomes an act of worship. Adhyātma-cetasā — with the mind anchored in the Self, not in the turbulent surface of results and reactions. Nirāśīḥ — no longing for what is not yet here. Nirmamaḥ — no clinging to what passes through the hands. And then the call: yudhyasva — fight. Act. Engage completely. And do so as vigata-jvaraḥ — one whose inner fever, the burning restlessness of the unliberated ego, has been healed by this surrender.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda calls this verse a summary of the entire bhakti-karma-jñāna synthesis that is the Gītā's gift. Surrender to Krishna (mayi) is the bhakti element. Adhyātma-cetasā — self-knowledge, keeping the mind in the Self — is the jñāna element. Sarvāṇi karmāṇi — performing all actions — is the karma yoga. These three streams are not separate paths here; they converge into a single movement. The word jvara is particularly significant: jvara is fever, the restless heat of anxiety, the burning of unfulfilled desire and unresolved fear. The Gītā's promise is cooling — not coldness, not detachment, but the peace that comes when the soul has found its true centre and no longer burns with the friction of misidentification.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda regarded this verse as the perfect summary of the devotional karma yogi's path. 'Mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi' — he taught this as a daily practice: before beginning any work, mentally offer it to the Divine; at its completion, offer the result. Over time, this offering becomes effortless and continuous, until the practitioner no longer experiences a gap between himself and God's activity in him. Vigata-jvaraḥ — freedom from the fever — Yogananda described as the state of divine calmness (prasāda) that floods the devotee who has truly surrendered. It is not emotional flatness but a living peace that co-exists with full engagement in the world — the peace that passes understanding, acting through a transparent, joyful instrument.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka identifies this verse as the practical heart of the Lord's instruction to Arjuna in this chapter, and notes its structural elegance: it provides the internal state (adhyātma-cetasā), the three freedoms (from hope, mine-ness, and fever), the method (surrender of all actions to God), and the action (fight — engage fully). Nothing is left vague. Goyandka emphasises that sannyasya here is not saffron robes and monastery walls; it is the internal act of releasing one's grip on outcomes, performed in the midst of whatever life requires of us. This is the Gītā's unique and revolutionary teaching: the highest renunciation is available in the middle of the battlefield, in the middle of the marketplace, in the middle of one's most demanding duties.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna begins by distinguishing two types of seekers: those who follow His teaching with śraddhā (faith) and without finding fault, and those who reject it. The word 'nityam' — always, constantly — reveals that spiritual practice must be uninterrupted, not merely occasional. 'Anasūyantaḥ' (without carping) is equally vital: intellectual ego often disguises itself as critical inquiry. The liberated person neither demands constant proof nor projects resistance onto wisdom. The promise 'mucyante karmabhiḥ' — freed from karma — means not the cessation of action, but freedom from the binding force of identification with the doer. Faith here is not blind belief but a receptive openness, a willingness to align one's inner life with divine truth as transmitted by the teacher.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda draws attention to the pair śraddhā and anasūyā as the twin prerequisites for genuine spiritual learning. Śraddhā is not superstition — it is the trust that makes a student capable of receiving wisdom rather than immediately deflecting it through argument. Anasūyā means freedom from envy or faultfinding: the ego's tendency to tear down what it cannot yet understand. Together these qualities create the inner vessel that can hold transformative knowledge. The result — liberation from karma — is not earned by effort alone but flows naturally when knowledge is properly received and lived. This verse makes clear that the Gita's teaching is not intellectual content but a way of being, and its fruit is freedom.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda comments that the devotee who practices Krishna's teaching with unwavering faith plants seeds of divine liberation in every action. 'Nityam' — constantly — is the key word: the spiritual aspirant does not switch between the divine and the mundane but sustains an unbroken thread of consciousness. Śraddhā, the faith born of direct inner experience, distinguishes true devotion from mere ritual compliance. And anasūyā — the absence of jealousy and carping — ensures the ego does not poison the well of wisdom from within. Such sincere practitioners are not bound by the results of their karma; their actions, performed in the spirit of offering to God, no longer generate the chain of cause and effect that perpetuates rebirth.
commentary.goyandka: Shri Jayadayal Goyandka notes that Krishna here promises liberation to those who follow His word with two essential virtues: faith and absence of malice. The person of faith takes the Lord's instruction as authoritative and does not subordinate it to personal preference or cleverness. The faultfinder, by contrast, is inwardly resistant — even if their outer behaviour conforms, the inner attitude negates the benefit. Liberation from karma does not mean one stops acting; it means one's actions no longer bind because they are performed without the ownership of doership. These verses serve as both an encouragement and a warning: the teaching is powerful, but its power is accessible only to those who approach it with the right inner disposition.

commentary.dadaji: This verse is the sober counterpart to the previous one. The word 'abhyasūyantaḥ' — those who actively carp and find fault — describes not genuine inquiry but the egoic habit of dismissing truth to protect one's current worldview. Krishna says such people are 'sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāḥ': deluded not in some knowledge but in all knowledge. This is a penetrating insight — when the foundational orientation is resistant and envious, every level of knowing becomes distorted. 'Naṣṭān acetasaḥ' — lost, without consciousness — is not a condemnation but a diagnosis. The remedy is not punishment but a return to śraddhā. This verse urges us to examine our own tendency to reject teachings that disturb our comfort, recognising that such rejection, however sophisticated it sounds, is ultimately a form of self-destruction.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda points out that the word 'tu' (but) in this verse creates a sharp contrast with the preceding one. The previous verse offered liberation; this one diagnoses loss. The person who carps is not merely wrong intellectually — they are 'vimūḍha' in all knowledge, meaning their capacity for discernment is perverted from the root. The Gita does not treat spiritual ignorance as neutral; it has active consequences. To reject the teaching of karma yoga — doing one's duty without selfish attachment — is to remain bound to the cycle of compulsive action and reaction. 'Acetasaḥ' literally means 'without consciousness' — suggesting that faultfinding, far from being a sign of keen intellect, is actually a failure of awareness.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda observes that this verse delivers a compassionate warning. Those who mock or ignore the divine teaching of selfless action are not merely missing an opportunity — they are actively reinforcing the very delusion that keeps them bound. 'Sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhān' is striking: they are deluded in ALL knowledge, not merely ignorant of spiritual matters. When the divine law is rejected, one's entire framework of understanding becomes distorted because the Source of true knowing is shut out. Yogananda urges practitioners not to become spiritually arrogant upon reading this verse but to use it as a mirror — examining where in their own lives they resist divine guidance in favour of personal preference or intellectual pride.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that the twin description 'naṣṭān acetasaḥ' — lost and without wisdom — indicates the cumulative effect of faultfinding. It is not a single act of rejection that destroys, but the habitual attitude of carping that gradually erodes one's discrimination. The person loses first the ability to recognise truth, then the very desire to seek it. The teaching of nishkama karma (desireless action in accordance with dharma) is not arbitrary; it reflects the structure of the universe. To reject it is therefore not merely a philosophical error but a fundamental misalignment with reality itself. Goyandka urges readers to cultivate humility before sacred wisdom and to distinguish genuine questioning from the ego's self-protective resistance.

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the Gita's most psychologically penetrating verses. Even the person of wisdom — 'jñānavān api' — acts according to their own nature. The word 'prakṛti' here encompasses one's accumulated tendencies, conditioning, and guṇa-composition. The rhetorical question 'nigrahaḥ kiṃ kariṣyati?' — what will mere restraint do? — does not endorse passivity or abandon ethics. Rather, it points beyond surface suppression to the need for transformation of nature itself. Merely forcing the body or senses to comply while leaving the inner disposition unchanged is futile. True freedom arises not from restraint but from the purification and eventual transcendence of one's lower nature through sustained practice, devotion, and the cultivation of the witness-self.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that this verse should not be read as fatalism — Krishna is not saying that one is helpless before nature. Rather, He is distinguishing two levels of engagement: external restraint (nigraha) versus internal transformation. All beings, including the learned, express their accumulated nature. The question 'what will restraint do?' points to the inadequacy of willpower alone as a spiritual method. What is needed is a change in the very quality of one's being — a shift in the guṇas — achieved through the karma yoga described in this chapter. Restraint without inner transformation creates conflict and repression; practice with right understanding transforms the nature from which action flows.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda reads this verse as an honest acknowledgement of the power of habitual tendencies (samskaras). Even the greatest sages carry residual prakriti. The solution, Yogananda emphasises, is not to fight nature on its own terms through brute will but to go deeper — to the Self beyond prakriti — through meditation, devotion, and surrender to God. When consciousness is anchored in the Self, the pull of lower nature loses its compulsive force. 'Nigrahaḥ kiṃ kariṣyati?' is Krishna's gentle prod: stop struggling at the surface and dive to the source. Transformation begins at the level of consciousness, not at the level of behavior alone.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka explains that this verse acknowledges a fundamental truth about the embodied being: our actions are deeply conditioned by the three guṇas composing our particular nature. This is not a license for inaction but a call for discernment about the kind of effort required. Mechanical suppression of desires through force of will alone merely pushes them underground. The Gita's path involves a subtler work: performing one's natural duties without attachment, gradually purifying the guṇas through association with sattva, and ultimately transcending all three through the steady practice of nishkama karma and devotion to God. Mere external nigraha, unsupported by inner transformation, is insufficient for liberation.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna now moves from the philosophical (nature-driven action) to the practical: the specific mechanism of bondage. Rāga (attraction) and dveṣa (aversion) are not incidental emotions — they are described as 'vyavasthitau', firmly stationed in each sense-faculty. This means the mechanism of attachment is built into the very structure of embodied perception. The warning 'tayor na vaśam āgacchet' — do not come under their sway — does not mean eliminate rāga and dveṣa immediately, which is impossible by an act of will, but means: do not let them make your decisions. The practitioner of karma yoga becomes a witness to these pulls without being swept away. Calling them 'paripanthinau' — enemies on the path — is precise: they do not destroy the aspirant outright but subtly redirect them away from liberation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that this verse provides a map of spiritual pitfalls embedded in ordinary perception. Every sensory encounter carries embedded attraction or aversion — this is simply how the conditioned mind experiences the world. The teaching is not to become insensible but to develop the skill of engaging the world without being governed by these reactive pulls. The term 'paripanthinau' is especially significant: pari-pantha means one who waits by the roadside to waylay a traveller. Rāga and dveṣa are exactly this — they appear innocent, even natural, but over time they steer the aspirant away from the path of wisdom. Awareness of their presence is the first act of spiritual intelligence.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda meditates on the dual nature of rāga and dveṣa as the twin forces sustaining the wheel of rebirth. Every attachment creates a demand for satisfaction; every aversion creates a demand for avoidance. Both bind the consciousness to the object. The only escape is not through exhaustion of desires — which simply generates new ones — but through the shift of identity from the sense-self to the soul. In meditation and devotion, the practitioner discovers a joy that does not depend on sensory objects, and from that stability they can act in the world without being controlled by like or dislike. Yogananda calls this the practical meaning of 'samatvam' — equanimity — described throughout Chapter Two.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka emphasises the phrase 'indriyasyendriyasya arthe' — rāga and dveṣa are present in each sense, not just one. This is comprehensive: the eye desires pleasant forms, the ear pleasant sounds, the tongue pleasant tastes, and so on. The entire sensory apparatus is saturated with these two tendencies. To become enslaved to them is therefore not unusual — it is the default condition of the unwise person. The Gita's instruction is to remain the master of the senses rather than their servant. This does not require the annihilation of sense function but rather their regulation by discriminative wisdom (viveka), so that actions are chosen according to dharma rather than impulse.

commentary.dadaji: This verse is a cornerstone of the Gita's ethical teaching and must not be reduced to caste orthodoxy. Svadharma means the path that is genuinely one's own — arising from one's spiritual constitution, temperament, and soul-calling — not simply a role assigned by birth. The comparison is stark: even an imperfectly followed personal dharma ('viguṇaḥ') is superior to another's dharma brilliantly executed, because inauthenticity — no matter how impressive — does not lead to liberation. 'Sva-dharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ' — death in one's own duty is better — echoes Krishna's earlier counsel to Arjuna: your dharma as a warrior, however painful, is your path to transcendence. Imitating another's path, however beautiful it appears from outside, leads only to inner fragmentation and fear.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that the concept of svadharma here operates on multiple levels simultaneously — social, psychological, and spiritual. At the social level it means performing the duties appropriate to one's station without envying others. At the psychological level it means acting from one's own deepest nature rather than performing a role borrowed from another. At the spiritual level it points to the unique path of each soul toward the divine. 'Para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ' — another's dharma brings fear — because living inauthentically creates an ongoing internal conflict between one's actual nature and one's performed identity. This internal warfare is more dangerous than the external battle Arjuna faced on the Kurukshetra field.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda interprets svadharma primarily in its inner, spiritual sense: the unique soul-path of each individual toward God-realisation. No two paths to the divine are identical, just as no two souls are identical. To copy another's spiritual method without discernment — even if that method is genuinely great for another — is to abandon one's own unique relationship with God. 'Para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ' warns that this substitution ultimately generates spiritual confusion and anxiety. Yogananda emphasises that the Gita's insistence on svadharma is not restrictive but liberating: it is an invitation to discover and honour the particular form of one's own divine calling rather than seeking safety in imitation.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka approaches this verse in the context of the Gita's warning against social disruption and personal imitation. He notes that the verse specifically states 'viguṇaḥ' — even if one's own dharma is imperfect, deficient, or not well executed — it remains superior to another's dharma perfectly performed. This is because authentic engagement with one's own path, however fumbling, aligns the individual with the divine order (ṛta) that structures their existence. Performing another's dharma well may produce worldly success but does not purify one's inner nature or advance liberation. Goyandka connects this to the broader teaching of nishkama karma: do your own work, without attachment to results, and spiritual progress will follow.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna asks one of the most profound questions in all of spiritual literature: what compels a person to act sinfully against their own wish? 'Anicchann api' — even while unwilling — acknowledges that the human being is not simply a rational agent freely choosing good or evil. There is a force at work that overrides choice. Arjuna uses the image 'balād iva niyojitaḥ' — as if yoked by force — which is psychologically precise: anyone who has struggled with an impulse they know is harmful and yet felt compelled toward it recognises this description. This question sets up Krishna's most important psychological teaching in the Gita: the identification of kāma (desire) and krodha (anger) as the deep mechanisms of bondage. Arjuna's courage in asking this honestly is itself a spiritual act.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that Arjuna's question in this verse moves the dialogue from cosmology and ethics into depth psychology. The key phrase is 'anicchann api' — even unwillingly. This is not a question about deliberate wrongdoing but about compulsion: why does a person act against their own better judgment? This is precisely the question that modern psychology attempts to address through the study of unconscious motivation and addiction. Krishna's forthcoming answer — kāma and krodha — is not moralistic but analytical. It identifies the specific psychological forces behind sinful compulsion. Arjuna's use of 'vārṣṇeya' (kinsman of Krishna's clan) is intimate, reflecting the depth of trust in this dialogue.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda observes that Arjuna has now arrived at the deepest level of the spiritual problem. Earlier in the chapter, he was told to control the senses; now he asks what the controller of the controller is — what force is so powerful that even the willing cannot resist it? This is not theoretical: every sincere aspirant has experienced the phenomenon of performing actions they regret and did not consciously choose. Yogananda explains that the answer lies in the accumulated force of past desires — the samskaras — which have gained momentum over many incarnations and express themselves through the physical and mental instruments as compulsive tendencies. Krishna's response in the next verses names this force and shows how to face it.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that Arjuna's question demonstrates his sincere desire to understand — not to make excuses — the mechanism of moral failure. 'Bala iva niyojitaḥ' — as if compelled by force — is the honest confession of one who has observed the gap between intention and action. This gap is universal in human experience; the Gita takes it seriously and addresses it directly. Goyandka sees in this question the transition point of the chapter: the first part (verses 1–35) addressed the philosophy and duty of action; the second part (verses 36–43) will address the psychology of bondage and the path to freedom from the inner enemy. Arjuna's inquiry is the hinge that opens this deeper teaching.

They are thy true opponents, not Arjuna's kinsmen.'

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the pivotal verses of the entire Gita. Krishna's answer to Arjuna's question is immediate and unambiguous: 'kāma eṣa krodha eṣa' — it is this, desire; it is this, anger. The repetition with 'eṣa' is emphatic — as if pointing a finger directly at the culprit. Kāma (desire) is the primary force; krodha (anger) is desire obstructed — the secondary explosion when desire meets resistance. Both spring from rajas, the principle of passionate activity. Krishna names desire as 'mahāśana' — all-devouring — because it is never satisfied: each fulfilment creates a greater hunger. It is also 'mahā-pāpmā' — greatly sinful — not in a moralistic sense but because it perpetuates ignorance of the true Self. The imperative 'viddhi enam vairiṇam' — know this as your enemy — is not a call to suppress desire through hatred but to recognise it clearly with the intelligence.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda regards this verse as Krishna's supreme diagnostic moment. The enemy is not external — not Duryodhana, not circumstance — but desire itself, and its transformation into anger when thwarted. 'Rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ' locates the origin precisely: rajas, the quality of restless passion, is the matrix from which both arise. The two epithets are penetrating: mahāśana (devourer) captures desire's insatiability — more is always needed — while mahā-pāpmā (greatly sinful) indicates that unrestrained desire is not just personally harmful but ontologically corrosive, severing one's connection with truth. Sarvapriyananda notes that the Gita does not ask one to kill desire (which is impossible) but to see it clearly, name it, and refuse to be governed by it.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda meditates on kāma as the fundamental force of extroversion — the outward pull of consciousness toward sense objects that constitutes the essence of avidyā (ignorance). When kāma is satisfied it creates temporary pleasure and a desire for more; when frustrated it generates krodha (anger). Yogananda sees in this analysis the exact mechanism of human suffering: consciousness, which is inherently blissful in its own nature, turns outward through desire and experiences the inevitable cycle of temporary satisfaction and renewed craving. The solution is not mortification but inversion of direction — through meditation and devotion, the same force of desire is turned toward God (bhakti), consuming itself in the infinite Object that alone can truly satisfy.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka focuses on the compound 'rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ' — completely born of the rajas quality. This is significant: kāma and krodha are not permanent features of human nature but specific expressions of the rajas-guṇa predominating in the individual. This means they are not ineradicable: by cultivating sattva through right conduct, right association, right diet, and devotion to God, the grip of rajas — and therefore of desire and anger — can be progressively loosened. Goyandka also notes the significance of 'iha vairiṇam' — the enemy here, in this world, in this very life. The battle against desire is not deferred to a future incarnation but is the immediate work of every sincere aspirant.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna employs three ascending images to illuminate how desire envelops knowledge. The smoke-and-fire analogy is the most accessible: smoke does not extinguish fire but makes it difficult to see or use it directly. Similarly, desire clouds knowledge without destroying it — the knowledge is still there, but inaccessible. The dust-on-mirror image is subtler: a mirror that is dusty cannot reflect clearly; it shows distorted images. Knowledge veiled by desire does not disappear but distorts: one sees what one wants to see. Most profound is the embryo-in-womb analogy: here the covering is total, organic, and formative — knowledge is not just obscured but has not yet emerged into light. These three images represent progressively deeper degrees of knowledge-concealment corresponding to different levels of desire's hold.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda interprets the three analogies as a graduated teaching. The smoke-fire example shows how knowledge and desire can coexist — fire continues to burn under smoke, and similarly awareness persists under the veil of desire. The dust-mirror example shows how the reflecting capacity of intellect (buddhi) is impaired: the mirror is still there but cannot serve its purpose. The embryo-womb analogy suggests a state of complete enclosure where knowledge exists as potential but has no avenue of expression. Sarvapriyananda notes that these three cover respectively: jñāna (general knowledge), viveka (discrimination), and self-knowledge — the deepest form being most completely hidden by desire.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda finds in this verse a profound description of the spiritual condition of ordinary human beings. Like the embryo enclosed in the womb, the soul is present and alive but has not yet emerged into the full light of Self-knowledge. Desire is the womb of spiritual immaturity. The process of sadhana — spiritual practice — is precisely the birthing process: gradually the veils of desire are thinned and finally removed, allowing the Self to emerge into its own natural luminosity. Yogananda connects this to the Vedantic teaching of sat-chit-ānanda: the soul is inherently consciousness-bliss, but desire wraps it in the three bodies (gross, subtle, causal) that obscure this truth.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka draws attention to the logical structure of these three analogies in terms of removability. Smoke from fire disperses easily in wind. Dust from a mirror can be wiped away. But the womb-covering of an embryo must be dissolved over time through the natural maturation process. This suggests that the degree to which desire has enveloped knowledge varies among individuals, and accordingly the effort required to remove the veil also varies. For those whose desire is like smoke — already thin — a single teaching may suffice to reveal the Self. For those whose covering is like an embryo's membrane — thick and organic — sustained, patient practice over time is required. This verse counsels neither despair nor complacency.

commentary.dadaji: This verse deepens the previous analogy by introducing a crucial phrase: 'jñānino nitya-vairiṇā' — the constant enemy of the wise. This is significant: even the jñānī (one possessed of knowledge) is targeted by desire. Desire does not simply prey on the ignorant; it is the nitya-vairiṇa — the perpetual, constitutional enemy of all who seek wisdom. 'Kāma-rūpeṇa analena' — by the fire in the form of desire — fuses two images: desire as an entity with a definite form (rūpa) and desire as fire (anala — literally 'that which is never satisfied'). The Sanskrit word 'anala' itself encodes insatiability: a-nala means 'not enough'. Desire-as-fire is never quenched by feeding; fuel only intensifies it. This verse is Krishna's most direct characterisation of kāma as an active agent of spiritual warfare.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda is struck by the phrase 'nitya-vairiṇā' — the eternal enemy. This is not a temporary adversary encountered in difficult circumstances but a structural feature of conditioned existence: as long as one is embodied and operating through the guṇas, desire will seek to reassert dominance. 'Duṣpūreṇa analena' — the insatiable fire — explains why satisfaction of desires is not a strategy for liberation: each gratification restokes the flame. Sarvapriyananda connects this to the teaching of karma: each satisfied desire strengthens the saṃskāra (latent tendency) that will demand fulfilment again. The only route to genuine peace is recognition of desire's nature and the transcendence of one's identification with the desiring self.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda meditates on the extraordinary psychological precision of this verse. The description 'duṣpūreṇa analena' — insatiable fire — perfectly captures the phenomenology of desire: the more it is fed, the more it burns. This is the opposite of genuine spiritual joy, which is self-sustaining and increases with depth. Yogananda emphasises that desire feeds on the sense of lack — it is generated by the fundamental misidentification of the self with the body and senses, which are inherently in a state of incompleteness. The cure is not suppression but the discovery of the ānanda (bliss) of the Self, which being inherently full requires nothing external. When even a glimpse of this inner fullness is tasted in meditation, desire's hold begins to loosen.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that this verse elaborates on the enemy introduced in verse 37 with two devastating characterisations. First, it is 'nitya-vairiṇa' — the permanent enemy, not one that can be finally defeated in a single battle. This calls for constant vigilance rather than complacency. Second, it is 'duṣpūra' — that which cannot be filled. This is the philosophical root of desire's destructive power: it masquerades as something that will ultimately satisfy but by its nature never can. Goyandka emphasises the word 'jñānino' — even the jñānī's knowledge is covered by this enemy. This is not to discourage the pursuit of knowledge but to insist that intellectual knowledge alone, without devotion and surrender to God, cannot fully dislodge the deep-rooted force of desire.

commentary.dadaji: This verse provides a precise map of how desire operates through the human instrument. Its three seats — indriyāṇi (senses), manas (mind), buddhi (intellect) — represent a progression from periphery to core. Desire first captures the senses, creating impulse; then colonises the mind, creating habitual desire-patterns; and finally corrupts the buddhi itself, the faculty of discrimination, so that even reasoning becomes rationalisation in the service of desire. This last infiltration — the corruption of buddhi — is the most dangerous because it removes the very capacity to discern the enemy. 'Vimohayati eṣa dehinam' — this enemy deludes the embodied soul — makes clear that the target is the jīva, the individual self, which loses touch with its true identity. The prescription follows in the next verses: begin by reclaiming the outermost layer — the senses — and work inward.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that verse 40 provides the 'anatomy of temptation': desire installs itself not merely in one level of the human being but at every level — sensory, mental, and intellectual. This is why superficial restraint (nigraha) is insufficient, as noted in verse 33. A desire repressed at the sensory level simply resurfaces through the mind; a desire repressed at the mind level finds rationalisation in the intellect. The only complete resolution lies in the transcendence of all three through Self-knowledge — the recognition of the ātman that underlies and is untouched by these instruments. Sarvapriyananda connects this to the Vedantic analysis of the pañcakośas (five sheaths): desire permeates the annamaya, prāṇamaya, and manomaya kośas simultaneously.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda identifies the three seats of desire in this verse with three levels of spiritual practice. At the level of the senses, the practice is pratyāhāra — withdrawal of sensory attention inward. At the level of manas, it is dhāraṇā — concentration that quiets the mind's restless fluctuation. At the level of buddhi, it is dhyāna and samādhi — deep meditation that allows the pure awareness of the ātman to shine through the polished intellect undistorted by desire. The verse thus implicitly outlines the inner architecture of yoga practice: working from the outermost instrument toward the innermost self. The final revelation — that the Self is beyond even buddhi — comes in verses 42–43.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka highlights the grammatical structure of the verse: senses, manas, and buddhi are described as the 'adhiṣṭhāna' of desire — its base of operations. Desire does not float free but must operate through these instruments. This is actually good news, because it means desire can be dislodged by purifying and strengthening each instrument in turn. Goyandka recommends: control of the senses through sense-regulation and fasting; control of the mind through prayer, japa, and satsang; control of the intellect through viveka (discrimination) and the study of scripture. As each instrument is progressively freed from desire's grip, the individual's natural wisdom begins to shine. This is the practical programme implicit in Krishna's teaching.

commentary.dadaji: This verse provides the strategic instruction: begin with the senses ('ādau niyamya'), for they are the outermost and most accessible seat of desire. From there, work inward. But the ultimate command is 'prajahi' — slay, destroy — desire as the 'pāpmānam', the sinful destroyer of knowledge. The distinction between jñāna and vijñāna is significant: jñāna is theoretical or intellectual knowledge, while vijñāna is the knowledge born of direct inner experience and realisation. Desire destroys not only one's conceptual understanding of truth but also — and more crucially — one's direct living experience of it. The honorific address 'bharatarṣabha' (bull of the Bharatas) reminds Arjuna of his noble lineage and the strength available to him. This is not a counsel of defeat but of confident engagement with the inner enemy.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that 'ādau' — first — reveals the sequential strategy: begin at the outermost periphery and work inward. This is the wisdom of graduated practice. The Gita does not demand immediate and complete transformation of the deepest levels of the psyche; it recommends beginning where the aspirant is — at the level of sensory engagement with the world — and gradually claiming each level of the inner instrument back from desire's dominion. The compound 'jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam' is crucial: jñāna is knowledge in general, vijñāna is the special knowledge of direct experience — the gnosis that arises in meditation and samādhi. Desire destroys both levels, making even the most learned person spiritually blind if they have not overcome it.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda draws attention to the imperative 'prajahi' — slay, completely destroy. This is warrior language, and it is deliberate: the battle against desire is a genuine inner war, not a polite request or a mild suggestion. Yogananda notes that 'jñāna-vijñāna' refers to the two levels of God-knowledge: understanding God intellectually (jñāna) and experiencing God directly (vijñāna). Desire destroys the first by distorting one's understanding, and the second by preventing the deep inner stillness required for the divine experience. The path forward requires beginning with sensory regulation — not through violence toward the body but through the cultivation of inner stillness that makes sensory objects less compelling than the inner light.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that the verse gives a clear programme: 'niyamya' (having controlled) the senses as the first step, followed by 'prajahi' (completely abandoning) desire. This sequence is important — first regulate the outward instruments, then attack the inner root. One cannot slay the root without first having established some basic discipline at the peripheral level. Goyandka also emphasises 'vijñāna-nāśanam': desire destroys vijñāna, the direct knowledge of Brahman. This is why a person may accumulate vast amounts of scriptural knowledge and still remain bound — because desire has destroyed not the information but the inner experiential realisation that the information points toward. Outer learning without inner freedom from desire produces pride, not liberation.

commentary.dadaji: This verse presents in compressed form the Sāṃkhya-Vedāntic hierarchy of reality from gross to subtle to transcendent. The senses are superior to the gross body and its objects. The mind (manas) is superior to the senses, for it coordinates sensory experience. The intellect (buddhi) is superior to the mind, being the faculty of discrimination and judgment. But the verse's power lies in its final clause: 'yaḥ buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ' — that which is beyond even the intellect, that is it. This is the ātman — the pure witnessing consciousness that underlies and illumines all the other faculties. Identifying the Self with the ātman rather than with any of the instrument-levels is the foundation of liberation. This hierarchy is not merely theoretical; it is a practical map for where to take one's stand in spiritual practice.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda explains that this verse is a compressed version of the Kaṭha Upaniṣad's famous hierarchy (2.3.7: indriyebhyaḥ parā hy arthā arthebhyaś ca paraṃ manaḥ...). The traditional formulation is cited with 'āhuḥ' — they say, implying the ancient wisdom-tradition. The critical move is the final one: beyond buddhi is 'saḥ' — that, pointing with a finger that cannot name its object directly. This is the ātman, the pure subjectivity that is never an object, that illumines buddhi from within without being illumined by anything else. Sarvapriyananda notes that this hierarchy also indicates the strategy for overcoming desire: by progressively disidentifying from senses, mind, and intellect, and identifying with the witnessing Self, desire loses its substrate.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda describes this verse as the Gita's map of inner ascent. In samādhi, consciousness withdraws from the senses, then from the mind, then from the intellect, and finally rests in its own pure nature — the ātman. This is not the obliteration of personality but its clarification: the instruments are still present but the identification shifts from instrument to the Self that uses them. Yogananda connects 'saḥ' — that — to the Upaniṣadic 'tat tvam asi' (thou art That): the Self beyond intellect is none other than the cosmic Brahman. The recognition of this identity is moksha. This verse therefore contains in seed the entire programme of raja yoga as Patañjali would later systematise it.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka notes that this ascending hierarchy serves the practical purpose of showing the seeker where desire must ultimately be confronted. Desire at the sensory level is the most visible and the most commonly addressed. But desire embedded in the mind is subtler and stronger. Desire lodged in the intellect — in the form of intellectual pride, ideological attachment, or the desire for knowledge itself as a possession — is the subtlest and most difficult to recognise. The ātman alone, being beyond all three levels, is the vantage point from which desire in all its forms can be witnessed without being compelled. Goyandka therefore emphasises the cultivation of viveka (discrimination) as the means of ascending through these levels toward the Self.

जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā saṃstabhyātmānam ātmanā
jahi śatruṃ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṃ durāsadam
verses.translation: Thus knowing thy true Self — that which is beyond intellect, beyond mind, beyond senses, beyond the body — steady the lower self by the higher Self. O Mighty-armed Arjuna, slay this enemy in the form of desire that is so difficult to overcome. In the light of the eternal Self, no enemy can stand.

commentary.dadaji: This verse closes Chapter Three with a battle-cry that is simultaneously a philosophical synthesis and a call to inner action. 'Buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā' — having known that which is beyond the intellect — is the Vedantic prerequisite: the aspirant must first achieve the intellectual recognition that the Self transcends all instruments. But this knowledge must become more than intellectual. 'Saṃstabhyātmānam ātmanā' — steadying the self by the Self — is the yogic act: the lower self (conditioned ego operating through senses, mind, and intellect) is stabilised and supported by the higher Self (pure witnessing ātman). From this steady ground, the battle against desire — 'kāma-rūpaṃ durāsadam' — can be effectively waged. 'Durāsadam' (hard to overcome) is honest: Krishna does not minimise the difficulty. But with the Self as one's foundation, victory is possible. The address 'mahā-bāho' reminds Arjuna that the strength of the great-armed one is not only of body but of Spirit.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda identifies the key instruction of this verse as the reflexive construction 'ātmānam ātmanā' — the self by the Self. This is the Gita's method in miniature: the lower self (jīva, ego, the instrument-complex of senses, mind, and intellect) is to be steadied and ultimately transcended by identification with the higher Self (ātman, the pure witness). This is not an external resource but an internal one — the very consciousness that is already present and already free, veiled only by the habit of misidentification with the instruments. The chapter ends with 'durāsadam' — difficult to overcome — which is precise and important. No spiritual bypassing is offered here. Desire is a formidable enemy. But the weapon — Self-knowledge — is more formidable still.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda reads this closing verse as the entire teaching of yoga compressed into four phrases: know the Self (buddhvā), stabilise in the Self (saṃstabhya ātmanā), identify with the Self rather than the ego (ātmānam ātmanā), and then act from that ground (jahi śatrum). This is the sequence of genuine spiritual transformation: intellectual understanding, inner stabilisation through practice, experiential shift of identity, and the resulting freedom of action. 'Kāma-rūpaṃ durāsadam' — the enemy in the form of desire, hard to overcome — is met not by force of ego-will alone but by the infinitely greater force of the Self, which is none other than the divine Purusha dwelling in the heart. The 'great-armed Arjuna' is reminded that his truest strength is spiritual, not muscular.
commentary.goyandka: Goyandka concludes his commentary on Chapter Three by noting that this final verse provides the complete method in seed form. First, the means: 'buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā' — know the Self that transcends even the intellect. This knowledge is the sword. Second, the inner posture: 'saṃstabhya ātmānam ātmanā' — stabilise the ego-self in the higher Self. This stabilisation is achieved through sustained practice, devotion, and surrender to God. Third, the action: 'jahi śatruṃ kāma-rūpam' — from that established position, slay desire. Goyandka emphasises that 'durāsadam' should not discourage but motivate: the Gita would not describe so complete and powerful a method if the enemy were not genuinely formidable. The greatness of the teaching matches the greatness of the obstacle.
